Meet me tomorrow at the club. > mail/send tinypal #12345=Are you coming to the party? > mail/send &allfriends=Come to my club for a party tonight. > mail/send ~evaledattr=Where do you want to meet? > mail/send +social=Where do you want to meet for the next party? > mail/send @myfriend tinypal otherfriend +social=Let's go to the party! > mail/send player1 player2 ... playerX=hi! > mail/send player1,this is player2,player3,...,playerX=hi! For those with limited number of input lines, an alternative method for writing mail exists. For information on this, read the help files for 'mail write'. The /SEND switch for mail is optional. See Also: mail write, mail forward, mail reply, mail recall
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail send quick

Command: mail/send [@]<address list>=[<subject>//]<message> The address list can contain any number of recipients (up to the mush buffer limit) and can be one of the following: A player name A player number prefixed by a dbrief# A mail alias attribute located on the player prefixed by a & (this is just an attribute on yourself with a list of players) A global mail alias attribute prefixed by a +. A mail alias attribute location on optional target prefixed by a ~ character. This is evaluated like get_eval(). The different elements in the address list need to be separated by spaces. If you include the optional '@', all recipients of a mail message will see the complete list of recipients. (This will show up as a 'CC' list). To give an optional subject, enter text you want as a subject then separate that from the rest of the message with two /'s. (IE: // ) There is an exception to the '@'. Check @list options, if the To: is automatically added, the '@' character's behavior is reversed. You can break up mail with either spaces OR commas and duplicates are automatically stripped out. { help mail send2 for more, or help mail send examples for examples }
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail send2

Command: mail/send (CONTINUED) To use the alias "&alias", you would need an attribute on yourself called "alias". There are no restrictions on the name of the alias, except that if the alias doesn't exist on the player calling the command or is a bad mush attribute name, the mailer will not accept it. The attribute referenced by the &<alias> is another address list, and can also contain other aliases if desired. Any recursion will stop when the mush long_buffer length is reached. You may also use '~' to evaluate the attribute. Examples: > &FRIENDS me=Seawolf Ashen-Shugar Thorin > mail &friends=Hiya! > &ONLINE me=[lwho()] > mail ~online=hiya! To use the global alias '+alias', there would have to be a pre-defined global attribute defined. If the global attribute does not exist, the input is ignored as an illegal entry. To have a global alias set, notify the nearest royalty or higher of what you wish to use. The address list can be separated by either spaces or commas. Examples: > mail/alias Alias: wiz Contents: Wizard AdminJudge SlothTheWiz > mail +wiz=hello! This would send to the players 'Wizard, AdminJudge, and SlothTheWiz' For examples, see: mail send examples
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail sending

Topic: mail sending There are three ways that you can send mail with the mail system. Depending on which way you prefer, this will point you to the correct help files. 1. Brandy/Mux style mail. This is when you do 'mail user-list=subject' Look at : 'help mail send brandy' and 'help mail write cmdlist' Needed : The BRANDY_MAIL toggle (help brandy_mail) **NOTE**: @toggle me=brandy_mail to set it. Syntax : mail user(s)=subject mail/reply <msg#>=subject mail/forward <msg#> <user(s)>=subject Note: Brandy/MUX mail wrappers may be in place on your RhostMUSH. If it is, you may be able to use @mail like you're used to. 2. PennMUSH style mail. This is used for the PennMUSH style mailing. Needed : The BRANDY_MAIL toggle must be UNSET and PENN_MAIL toggle must be set. BRANDY_MAIL has precidence. Syntax : mail user(s)=subject/body Note: Penn mail wrappers may be in place on your RhostMUSH. If it is, you may be able to use @mail like you're used to. 3. RhostMUSH line editor. This is when you do 'mail/write <start of text>' Look at : 'help mail write' and 'help mail write cmdlist' Syntax : mail/write Start Of Message 4. Mailing quickly. This is when you do 'mail <user-list>=<subj>//<body>' Look at : 'help mail send quick' and 'help mail cmdlist' Needed : The BRANDY_MAIL toggle must NOT be set. **NOTE**: @toggle me=!brandy_mail to remove it. Syntax : mail user(s)=Optional Subject//Body mail user(s)=Body Please check @list options to see what current global settings are enabled for the mail system. Start a sendlist with a , for player's with spaces. See Also: PENN_MAIL, BRANDY_MAIL, mail write, mail send quick, mail send brandy
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail setup_aliases

Command: 1. mail/alias 2. wmail/alias[</switches>] [<alias-name>=<list of players>] 3. &ATTRIB me=<list of players> 4. &ATTRIB me=<eval returning list of players> 5. &ALIAS.NAME <mail_def_object>=<eval returning list of players> 6. &COMMENT.NAME <mail_def_object>=<label description for alias> There are various types of aliases you can set up. Below will be described each alias and how to set up each kind and use them. * Global Aliases Global aliases can only be created by a wizard. You can see what global aliases exist with 'mail/alias'. To use a global alias, you would use the '+' prefix. To create global aliases as a wizard, you use the 'wmail/alias' command. Example: mail +wizards=Hi! 1. Option '1' above is how you would see all the current global aliases. 2. Option '2' above is how a wizard would set a STATIC global alias. * Personal Aliases Personal aliases are actually nothing more than attributes you store on yourself. If you have friends called 'bob' 'terry' and 'james' you would set can set the alias like this: &friends me=bob terry james To use the personal STATIC alias, you would use the '&' prefix. To use the personal DYNAMIC (eval) alias, you would use the '~' prefix. 3. Option '3' above sets a static list of dbref#'s (or player names) that will be used as a personal alias you can then use in sending mail with '&'. Example: &FRIENDS me=Moe Larry Curley Shemp Joe mail &friends=Hi! 4. Option '4' works similar to option 3, except it is a function evaluation that then returns a list of player names or dbref#'s to use in a mail. You may also specify another target other than yourself. Example: &EVAL_FRIENDS MyObject=[get(Stooges/player_list)] mail ~MyObject/eval_friends=Hi! * Global Evaluated Aliases Evaluated aliases are similiar to static aliases. When a wizard sets these up, they work by evaluation so can be used to set up global dynamic aliases. These are referenced with a '$' prefix. This requires that the @admin config parameter 'mail_def_object' is defined. 5. Option '5' above sets the actual evaluated alias. 6. Option '6' just sets a label/description that is shown when a player lists the aliases. Example: mail $wizards=Hi! See Also: help mail send
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail share

Command: mail/share <key> Share lets you give access to your mailbox for other players who pass the lock. The key is a standard boolean lock expression, as documented in 'help @lock keys'. Any player who passes the lock may do the /number and /check sub-commands on your mailbox. If you do not have a share lock set on your mail, this is the same as if nobody can pass the share lock. To clear the lock, enter a blank expression. If you set a folder/share, players who pass the mail/share lock can only see the folder you specify. Examples: > mail/share *tinyspouse (allows tinyspouse into your mail) > mail/share *tinyspouse | *tinypal (allows tinyspouse and tinypal) > mail/share (removes the sharelock) The attribute is 'ShareLock' on yourself. See Also: mail number, mail check, mail folders, mail folder, mail share
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail signature

Command: &MAILSIG me=<string> mail signatures are done by storing a user-defined attribute on yourself. the attribute is called 'MAILSIG'. To set this attribute, you would do: &MAILSIG me=whatever you want as your signature. Please keep in mind that this attribute is *NOT* evaluated for functions and is taken as-is.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail status

Command: mail/status [[p#] [*player] [#-#] [U/N/B/O/M/S] [/SUBJECT]] This will print out a list of the message headers in the current folder for which the player has mail. This will also show the current folder. The p# argument (where # is an integer) will print out the specified page of message headers if the user has his/her paging value set. The page is determined from the paging value entered with the page command which represents the number of messages on a page. If the user has no paging value set, entering a page number on this command will have no effect. If the user has a paging value set and enters 0 for the page number, the user will get all message headers without any page breaks. Check out help on 'mail page' to see how to set your paging value. The '*player' option will show all mail sent to you from the given player, and the #-# is a range of messages you would like to see. The letters U, N, B, O, M, and S are the special character representations for: (U)nread (N)ew (B)oth new and unread (O)ld (M)arked (for deletion) (S)aved The /SUBJECT option will do a search for mail matching '/SUBJECT' in the subject field. The string after the '/' tells what to search for. { To continue with examples, see 'help mail status2' }
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail status2

Command: mail/status (continued) Mail status looks like the following: > mail/status ... [N] ( 5) From: Wizard <Sat Nov 5 14:00:05 1994> (113 bytes) [R] ( 6) *From: Seawolf <Fri Nov 4 12:23:02 1994> (200 bytes) Fwd Subj: In Reply to your mail. ... The letter in brackets indicates the status (old, new, unread, marked, saved) The corresponding letter will show what it is (O, N, U, M, S). The number following the status indicates the message number. The status also reports who sent the mail, when the mail was sent, and the size of the message. It also will show if the mail was forwarded, or replied to and any optional subjects that were included on the mail message. New mail becomes unread if you logout without reading it. The '*' shows the player connected. Examples: > mail/status (shows all your mail in your current folder) > mail/status p2 (shows second page of your mail [if page is set]) > mail/status 10-50 (shows messages 10-50 in your mailbox) > mail/status 5 (shows just message 5 in your mailbox) > mail/status *Seawolf (shows all mail from player Seawolf) > mail/status U (shows all the unread mail in your mailbox) > mail/status B (shows all the unread and new mail in your mailbox) > mail/status /biff (shows mail with subjects containing the word biff) > mail/status @folder (shows all your mail of the specified folder) See Also: mail number, mail read, mail mark, mail unmark, mail save, mail page
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail technical

Topic: technical information about the mail system The mail system was designed years ago and has gone through modifications which help compress it's mail storage architecture. Some of the technical information to the mail system is: - Multiple sent mail shares a single message for compactability - Mail system uses a separate database separate from the MUSH db. - Mail system is totally hard-code. No dependancy on mush version or objs. - Folder system is stored along with the mail db separate from the mush db. - Mail database can be dumped on-line for cross-platform backups/recovers. - Mail database can be loaded on-line (it *will* delete current mail db) - Mail system does not suffer corruption and other instabilities that softcoded mailers of similar functionality have. (Example: brandy mailer) - Allows some user-configurability for ease of use (to be expanded later) - Has full featured database recovery suite and index rebuilding incase of corruption by some remote off-chance. Current version of this writing is 2.1.1 Seawolf @ RhostMUSH
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail topics

Available Mail Topics are: mail-writing mail-reading mail-deleting mail-folders mail-admin mail-reviewing mail-sharing mail-examples mail-other mail-aliases mail-filtering mail-attributes A tutorial can be seen with: mail tutorial
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail tutorial

Topic: mail tutorial There are two different type of tutors. The first is if you wish to use the brandy mail interface to the system. The second is if you wish to just get on your feet with the mail system and learn the bare-bone basics (non-brandy interface) For the brandy interface tutorial (+mail & MUX/TM3 @mail), please type: help mail btutor For the penn interface tutorial (Penn @mail), please type: help mail ptutor For the default bare-bone tutorial, please type: help mail dtutor
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail uall

This is a sub-option to 'mail/read' (short for just 'mail'). If you specify 'uall' at the end, it will read ALL the unread mail messages you have in your mailbox. Example: > mail/read uall > mail uall See Also: mail ball, mail nall, mail new, mail unread, mail both
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail unmark

Command: mail/unmark <#>|all (this works for saved messages as well) This command is similar to mark except that it unmarks messages. You may use mark and unmark to mark all but specific messages. You can only unmark messages in the current folder. You would use this to unmark SAVED messages as well. Examples: > mail/mark all > mail/unmark tinyspouse (These two commands in this order mark all but tinyspouse's messages.) > mail/mark tinypal > mail/unmark 2 5 (These two commands in this order mark all of tinypal's messages, except messages 2 and 5). > mail/unmark 1-5 (unmark messages 1 through 5) See Also: mail mark, mail delete, mail status, mail save
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail unread

This is a sub-option to 'mail/read' (short for just 'mail'). If you specify 'unread' at the end, it will read the FIRST unread mail message in your mailbox. Example: > mail/read unread > mail unread See Also: mail uall, mail nall, mail ball, mail new, mail both
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail version

Command: mail/version this command will show the current version of the mailsystem.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write

Topic: mail writing Note: For help on creating new mail, please see 'help mail send' mail/write gives you the flexability of a line-editor within mail. There are various options with mail/write that you may use. Help is available on each of these topics. Topics: ADDING FORWARDING QUICKSENDING CMDLIST AUTONOTIFY EXAMPLES Write Functionality: - +edit +del +join +justify +split +insert +list +forward +reply +subject +forget +send +fedit +editall +feditall +cc +bcc +acc +proof Type: help mail write <option> for help on these topics/functionality.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +acc

Command: mail/write +acc=<player-list> The '+acc' subcommand is used to modify (add to) the target list of players the mail is going out to. Keep in mind, this ONLY works for sending or forwarding. This does *NOT* work for replies. This only works when you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL and when you start a message with 'mail player-list=subject' (or similiar). Example: > mail/write +acc=player1 player2 &myalias +globalalias Mail: New send player list stored. See Also: mail write +cc, mail write +bcc
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +bcc

Command: mail/write +bcc=<player-list> The '+bcc' subcommand is used to modify (add to) the target list and blind target list of players the mail is going out to. Keep in mind, this ONLY works for sending or forwarding. This does *NOT* work for replies. If 'bcc_hidden' is ENABLED, then whoever is in the +bcc list will _NOT_ see who the mail was sent to. If 'bcc_hidden' is DISABLED, then whoever is in the +bcc list WILL see who the mail was sent to, but no one outside the +bcc list will. In effect, bcc_hidden toggles the effect. Please check '@list options mail' for the current configuration. You may specify '!ALL' to clear the Bcc list without effecting the To list. This only works when you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL and when you start a message with 'mail player-list=subject' (or similiar). Example: > mail/write +bcc=player1 player2 &myalias +globalalias Mail: New send player list stored. See Also: mail write +cc, mail write +acc
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +cc

Command: mail/write +cc=<player-list> The '+cc' subcommand is used to replace (not modify!) the target list of players the mail is going out to. Keep in mind, this ONLY works for sending or forwarding. This does *NOT* work for replies. This only works when you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL and when you start a message with 'mail player-list=subject' (or similiar). Example: > mail/write +cc=player1 player2 &myalias +globalalias ~evalalias Mail: New send player list stored. See Also: mail write +bcc, mail write +acc
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +del

Command: mail/write +del=<args> The '+del' subcommand to mail/write is used to delete a line of text. Examples: > mail/write A line of text Mail: Write message started. > -Another line of txt Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of text 2: Another line of txt ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +del=1 Mail: Write line deleted. > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: Another line of txt ------------------------------------------------------------------------- Note: You can't delete line #1 if that's the only line there is. Use mail/write +forget to remove it. See Also: mail write +edit, mail write +split, mail write +forget
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +edit

Command: mail/write +edit <line>=<old>,<new> The '+edit' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit a line of text. This only edits the FIRST occurance of text in the line. Examples: > mail/write A line of text Mail: Write message started. > -Another line of txt Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of text 2: Another line of txt ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +edit 2=txt,text Mail: +edit done. > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of text 2: Another line of text ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +del, mail write +join, mail write +justify
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +editall

Command: mail/write +editall=<old>,<new> The '+editall' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit ALL lines of text. This only edits the FIRST occurance of text in the lines. Examples: > mail/write A line of txt txt Mail: Write message started. > -Another line of txt txt Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of txt 2: Another line of txt ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +editall=txt,text Mail: +editall done (2 lines edited) > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of text txt 2: Another line of text txt ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +feditall, mail write +edit, mail write +fedit
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +fedit

Command: mail/write +fedit <line>=<old>,<new> The '+fedit' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit a line of text. Unlike the '+edit' subcommand, this edits ALL occurances of the text in the line. Examples: > mail/write A line of text Mail: Write message started. > -Another line of txt Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of text 2: Another line of txt ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +fedit 2=txt,text Mail: +fedit done. > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of text 2: Another line of text ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +del, mail write +join, mail write +justify, mail write +fedit, mail write +editall, mail write +feditall
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +feditall

Command: mail/write +feditall=<old>,<new> The '+feditall' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit ALL lines of text. This edits ALL occurances of text in ALL the lines. Examples: > mail/write A line of txt txt Mail: Write message started. > -Another line of txt txt Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of txt 2: Another line of txt ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +feditall=txt,text Mail: +feditall done (2 lines edited) > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of text text 2: Another line of text text ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +editall, mail write +edit, mail write +fedit
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +forget

Command: mail/write +forget The '+forget' subcommand to mail/write is used to purge the mail in progress effectively deleting all of the mail/write information. Examples: > mail/write Start of message Mail: Write message started. > -another line Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: 1: Start of message 2: another line > mail/write +forget Mail: Write message forgotten. > mail/write +list Mail: No write in progress. See Also: mail write +edit, mail write +del
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +forward

Command: mail/write +forward=<message number> <player-list> The '+forward' subcommand to mail/write is used to forward the mail in progress to the player list while including the specified message number from your mailbox. Examples: > mail/write TinyPlayer sent me this... what do you think? Mail: Write message started. > mail/status ------------------------------------------------------------------------- [0] ( 1) From: TinyPlayer <Mon Jan 1 01:01:01 2000> (1095 Bytes) Subj: Hey! ------------------------------------------------------------------------- Note: if the player 'TinyPlayer' was connected, they'd have a '*' before the 'From:'. i.e. *From: TinyPlayer > mail/write +forward=1 MyFriend Mail: Message sent to -> MyFriend See Also: mail write +reply, mail write quicksending, mail forward mail status
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +insert

Command: mail/write +insert=<args> The '+insert' subcommand to mail/write is used to insert a line before the specified line. Examples: > mail/write Start of mail Mail: Write message started. > -Third line Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: Start of mail 2: Third line ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +insert=2,Second line Mail: Line inserted. > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: Start of mail 2: Second line 3: Third line ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +del, mail write +join
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +join

Command: mail/write +join=<args> The '+join' subcommand to mail/write is used to join two lines of text. Examples: > mail/write This is Mail: Write message started. > -This is the end of the line. Mail: Write line 2 added > -a test Mail: Write line 3 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: This is 2: This is the end of the line. 3: a test ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +join=1,3 Mail: Line joined. > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: This is a test 2: This is the end of the line. ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +del, mail write +split
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +justify

Command: mail/write +justify=<args> The '+justify' subcommand to mail/write is used to justify the line. Valid options are (l)eft, (c)enter, or (r)ight for justification. Examples: > mail/write This is a test Mail: Write message started. > -This is the end of the line. Mail: Write line 2 added > -ok, I lied. Mail: Write line 3 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: This is a test 2: This is the end of the line. 3: ok, I lied. ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +justify=1,c Mail: Line justified. > mail/write +justify=2,r Mail: Line justified. > mail/write +list ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: This is a test 2: This is the end of the line. 3: ok, I lied. ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +join, mail write +del
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +list

Command: mail/write +list [=<args>] The '+list' subcommand to mail/write is used to list the lines of your write message. Examples: > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: Line one 2: Line two 3: Line three ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +list=2 Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 2: Line two 3: Line three ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +list=1,2 Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: Line one 2: Line two ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +forget, mail write +send
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +proof

Command: mail/write +proof The '+proof' subcommand to mail/write is used to give you a 'snapshot' of approximately what the mail will look like when it is sent out. This does not show any text that will be included in forwarded or replied to mail if you chose the options to include original text. Examples: > mail/write This is some text Mail: Write message started. > mail/write +proof --------------------------------------------------------------------------- Message In Progress Status: EDITING From: You To: (empty list) Date/Time: Mon May 14 18:50:27 2011 Size: 18 Bytes Subject: (None) --------------------------------------------------------------------------- This is some text --------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +list, mail write
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +reply

Command: mail/write +reply=<message number> The '+reply' subcommand to mail/write is used to reply to the specified message with the mail that is in progress. Examples: > mail/write Thanks for the mail. Mail: Write message started. > mail/status ------------------------------------------------------------------------- [0] ( 1) From: TinyPlayer <Mon Jan 1 01:01:01 2000> (1095 Bytes) Subj: Hey! ------------------------------------------------------------------------- Note: if the player 'TinyPlayer' was connected, they'd have a '*' before the 'From:'. i.e. *From: TinyPlayer > mail/write +reply=1 Mail: Message sent to -> TinyPlayer See Also: mail write +forward, mail write quicksending, mail reply, mail status
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +send

Command: mail/write +send=<player list> The '+send' subcommand to mail/write is used to send the mail in progress to a list of players. You may specify a '@' before the player list to send the list of players in a seeable 'CC' list. Otherwise, it's assumed blank carbon copies for everyone in the mail list. Examples: > mail/write Start of message Mail: Write message started. > -second line. Mail: Write line 2 added > -third line. Mail: Write line 3 added > mail/write +send=@tinyplayer tinywizard Mail: Message sent to -> TinyPlayer Mail: Message sent to -> TinyWizard See Also: mail write +reply, mail write +forward, mail send, mail forward, mail reply, mail status
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +split

Command: mail/write +split=<args> The '+split' subcommand to mail/write is used to split a line after the specified word. Examples: > mail/write Start of mail Mail: Write message started. > -Second line Third line Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: Start of mail 2: Second line Third line ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +split=2,2 Mail: Line split. > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: Start of mail 2: Second line 3: Third line ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +justify, mail write +join, mail write +del
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write +subject

Command: mail/write +subject=<subject> The '+subject' subcommand to mail/write is used to set a subject line for your mail message. You may use this command to also re-set it to something else if you so desire. Examples: > mail/write Start of message Mail: Write message started. > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: 1: Start of message > mail/write +subject=My Subject Mail: Write subject set > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: Subject: My Subject 1: Start of message See Also: mail write +send, mail write -, mail write +forget
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write -

Command: mail/write <text> -<text> The '-' subcommand is used to continue lines of text after the initial 'mail/write' was used to start the mail message. This is used in juncture with sending, forwarding, or replying to mail using the line editor. This command will NOT be recognized as a valid command if you did not use mail/write previous to it! Example: > -this is a line of text Huh? (Type 'help' for help.) > mail/write I forgot to start the message first! Mail: Write message started (37/32758). > -this is a line of text Mail: Write line 2 added (60/32758) > mail/write another line of text Mail: Write line 3 added (81/32758) See Also: mail write cmdlist, mail write adding
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write adding

Topic: mail write adding text There are two ways to write mail using the mail/write method. You can use mail/write to save text, or, after using mail/write for the first line (to initialize the mail message being written) you may use a '-' to continue writing lines of text. mail/write (used to initialize mail writing and write first line) - (can be used instead of mail/write to write additional lines) mail/write +subject=<text> (used to add the subject) Example: > mail/write My first line of the mail Mail: Write message started. > -My second line of the mail Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +subject=My Subject Mail: Write subject set > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- Subject: My Subject ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: My first line of the mail 2: My second line of the mail ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail send, mail write forwarding
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write autonotify

Topic: mail write auto notification If for whatever reason you got disconnected during a mail write, you will be notified that you have a mail write in progress. Just type mail/write +list And you will see what the message you have in progress is. If you want to purge it, just type mail/write +forget And the message will be forgotten (purged/tossed). See Also: mail write cmdlist
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write cmdlist

Topic: mail write command list mail/write <message> - Start new mail/Add new line - - Add new line of text mail/write +edit <line #>=<old txt>,<new txt> - Edit first text on line mail/write +fedit <line #>=<old txt>,<new txt> - Edit all text on line mail/write +editall=<old text>,<new text> - Edit first text everywhere mail/write +feditall=<old text>,<new text> - Edit all text everywhere mail/write +cc=<player list> * resets player list mail/write +bcc=<player list> * Adds to player and bcc list mail/write +acc=<player list> * Adds to player list mail/write +del=<line #> - Delete line mail/write +join=<line #>,<line #> - Join lines mail/write +justify=<line #>,[l,r,c] - Justify the line mail/write +split=<line #>,<after word #> - Split line at character mail/write +insert=<line #>,<text> - Insert text at line mail/write +list [=<line #>,<line #>] - List line(s) (proofs) mail/write +proof - Displays in 'sent' format. mail/write +send=[@]<player list> - Send mail to players mail/write +forward=<mail #> [@] <player list> - Forward mail to players mail/write +reply=<mail #> - Replys to sender (sends) mail/write +subject=<text> - Add (change) subject mail/write +forget - Toss the mail in progress Topics with '*' only work with the BRANDY_MAIL interface. This is the 'editor' way to send, forward, or reply to mail. for descriptions, type: help mail write cmdlist2
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write cmdlist2

Topic: mail write command list (continued) The first format (mail/write <message>) will start a new message or append the message to an existing message in the mail editor. If you have the BRANDY_MAIL toggle set, you may initiate the line editor with 'mail player-list=subject'. To change text, use the +edit sub-command of write to change <old text> to <new text>. You can't use braces to group the old and new text, but you can use angle brackets (<>) to group the old text. Use +list to check the current status of the message. See 'help mail line' for information on line editing. To send the message, or send it as a reply or part of a forwarded message, use the +send, +reply, or +forward sub-commands of write. To cancel (erase) the current message in the editor, use the +forget sub-command. You can only +reply to and +forward messages in the current folder. To add a subject (or remove it) use the +subject option with write. For examples: help mail write examples.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write examples

Topic: mail write examples Examples: > mail/write I am sending you a long message. > mail/write It just goes on and on. > -And I can use the '-' to continue adding lines of text! > mail/write +edit 1=long,very long > mail/write +list > mail/write +subject=Read this! > mail/write +send=tinypal tinyfriend This message would read: I am sending you a very long message. It just goes on and on. And I can use the '-' to continue adding lines of text! It would also have a subject of 'Read This!'. See Also: mail send, mail forward, mail reply
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write forwarding

Topic: mail write forwarding To forward mail using the line editor, it takes a bit of reverse logic. You must FIRST start writing the message, THEN you specify you want to forward it to the player list. mail/write (used to initialize mail writing and write first line) - (can be used instead of mail/write to write additional lines) mail/write +forward=<message #> [@] <player list> The last line will forward your message to the specified player list and include the message# of the message in your mailbox. See help on mail write +forward for more information on the forward command. See Also: mail write +forward, mail write +reply, mail write
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail write quicksending

Topic: mail write quicksending To send mail quickly, you can use the default behavior of mail. The syntax for a quick message is as follows: mail/send [@] <player-list> = [optional subject//] Message Body This fires off the mail without initiating the line editor. The /send switch is optional, unless you are toggled BRANDY_MAIL, in which case, the /send switch is required. Yes, you can use a quick message to send a mail message while in the middle of a line editor in writing a different mail message. See Also: mail send, mail
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail writing

Please see 'help mail send'
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail zap

Command: mail/zap This option will automatically mark the present message and view the next message. For example, if you typed: mail 1 you would read mail message #1 (if you had mail) If you typed: mail/zap You would mark message #1 for deletion and read message #2 (if you had two messages, in which it would only mark #1 and return that you had no more mail to read) Note: If you add a '-' after zap (i.e. mail/zap -) it will read the previous message. See Also: mail status, mail next, mail mark, mail delete, mail read
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail-admin

See 'wizhelp mail' and 'wizhelp wmail'.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail-aliases

There are multiple ways to have aliases in RhostMUSH. The standard method is for global mail aliases. Only wizards may set, modify, or remove global mail aliases. You may see global mail aliases by typing: mail/alias This command will show all the global mail alises, if it's a static mail alias or a dynamic mail alias, or if there's any locks that make it so you can not use them. To use a static mail alias, you would prepend a '+' before the alias. Such as: mail +wizards=To all Wizards! For dynamic mail aliases, you would prepend a '$' before the alias. mail $wizards=To all Wizards! You will see with mail/alias if it's a static global (+) or a dynamic global ($) mail alias to help avoid confusion. {see 'help mail-aliases2' for personal mail aliases}
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail-aliases2

There is a third method for aliases. These are considered personal mail aliases, and anyone may set them. To set them, you just store an attribute on yourself containing a list of players. This field can not be evaluated. An example of a personal mail alias would be: &myfriends me=Bob Sarah #456 Julie @set me=myfriends:Bob Sarah #456 Julie Either sets an alias for Bob, Sarah, player #456, and Julie. Any non-players will automatically be stripped in the sending of the mail (with appropiate warning messages). To use a personal alias, you would use the key field '&' to identify to the mail system that it is a personal mail alias. mail &myfriends=To all of my friends! For help on setting attributes, please check help for '&' or '@set'.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail-attributes

Topic: MAIL ATTRIBUTES The following attributes have special meaning in the mail system. @mailsig -- The signature that is assigned to any mail sent. &mailfilter -- This is evaluated to auto-filter what folder mail goes to. &mailnotify -- This is evaluated to auto-send notification to senders. @mailtime -- (Wizard only) Sets the auto-delete time on a player. @mailsmax -- (Wizard only) Sets the maximum saved messages on a player. MailLock -- (Internal) This is the lock mail/lock sets The following wildcard patterns are used for mail: mail &foo=text -- This will check your personal FOO attribute for the player list you want to send to. This is non-evaluated. mail ~foo=text -- This will check your personal FOO attribute for the player list you want to send to. This is evaluated. See Also: @mailsig, &mailfilter, &mailnotify, mail lock, mail setup_aliases For wizards, wizhelp: @mailsmax, @mailtime
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail-deleting

The following is used to delete mail: 1) mail/mark <range|message|*player> [help mail mark] - This marks the message(s) for deleting. 2) mail/mark/save <range|message|*player> [help mail save] - This marks the message(s) for saving from deleting. 3) mail/unmark <range|message|*player> [help mail unmark] - This removes the mark from the message 4) mail/unmark <range|message|*player> [help mail save] - This removes the saved mark from the message 5) mail/delete [help mail delete] - This purges the mail that was marked. 6) mail/status - This lists your mail (with the marks) See Also: mail mark, mail save, mail unmark, mail delete, mail status
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail-examples

See 'help mail write cmdlist', 'help mail cmdlist', 'help mail quicklist', 'help folder cmdlist'
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail-filtering

You can specify mail filtering by using the MAILFILTER attribute. This allows you filter incoming mail by either the target player or the subject. If the mail was sent anonymously, the player is returned as #-1, otherwise the dbref# of the player will be returned. For detailed help, see help for MAILFILTER See Also: MAILFILTER
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail-folders

The folders command are controlled with the 'folder' command. Please refer to 'help folder cmdlist' for the listing. See Also: mail main, mail topics, mail cmdlist
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail-other

See 'help mail cmdlist', 'help mail quicklist', 'help mail write cmdlist', 'help folder cmdlist'
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail-reading

The following commands are used to read the mail: 1) mail new [help mail new] - This reads the first new message 2) mail nall [help mail nall] - This reads ALL new mail messages (can be spammy). 3) mail unread [help mail unread] - This reads the first unread message 4) mail uall [help mail uall] - This reads ALL unread mail messages (can be spammy). 5) mail both [help mail both] - This reads the first new OR unread message 6) mail ball [help mail ball] - This reads BOTH ALL unread AND new mail messages (can be spammy). 7) mail # [help mail read] - This reads the specified message #. 8) mail/status [help mail status] - This displays all the mail in your mailbox 9) mail/quick [help mail quick] - This gives you a quick status of your mailbox. 10) mail +all - This will read all your mail. 11) mail/read/save - This option will output mail in an MBOX format See Also: mail quick, mail status, mail read, mail topics, mail main
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail-reviewing

The following is used for reviewing mail: 1) mail/status [help mail staus] - List your mail 2) mail/quick [help mail quick] - Gives status report of mailbox 3) mail/recall [help mail recall] - Shows listing of all mail you sent that's not been read 4) mail/recall # - Views the sent message 5) mail/recall #=[+all|player(s)] - Yanks the specified player(s) (or all) from receiving the mail. See Also: mail recall, mail quick, mail status
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail-sharing

The following commands are used to share a mailbox with a friend: 1) mail/share <key> [help mail share] - You may refer to 'help @lock keys' on how to set this. 2) folder/share <mailbox> [help folder share] - This identifies what folder(s) you wish to share. Those who pass the mail/share lock above, will be able to see the folders. 3) mail/number <player> [help mail number] - This lists the message(s) of the player you're sharing mail with. 4) mail/check <player>=<message> [help mail check] - This reads the specified message in player's shared folders Note: all folders are combined that you can share. See Also: mail share, folder share, mail topics, mail main
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail-writing

The following commands exist for writing new mail messages: 1) Brandy/@mail A) @toggle me=brandy_mail mail_stripreturn [set up interface] B) mail[/forward|reply] <player(s)>=<subj> [start message] C) -<new line of text> [add new text] D) mail/write +feditall=old,new [edit text] E) mail/write +forget [toss message] F) mail/write +subject=<text> [reset the subject] G) mail/write +acc=<players> [append to players] H) mail/write +cc=<players> [reset the players] I-1) -- [send off mail] (or) I-2) -~ [send mail anonymously] J) mail/send <player(s)>=<subject>//<body> [quick-send of mail] 2) PENN @mail A) @toggle me=!brandy_mail penn_mail [set up interface] B) mail <player-list>=<subject>/<body> [send message] 3) Seawolf(Rhost) Mail A) mail <player-list>=<subject>//<body> [send mail - type 1] B1) mail/write <start of text> [first line of text] B2) -<new line of text> [add new text] B3) mail/write +subject=<subject> [set subject] B4) mail/write [+send|+forward|+reply]=<players> [send message - type 2] B5) mail/write/anon [+send|+forward|+reply]=<pl> [send anonymously -tp 3] See Also: mail main, mail topics, mail cmdlist, mail write cmdlist
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/alias

Command: mail/alias The alias switch is used to display any global alias you have permission to access and will list all players that are attached to that global alias. Global aliases are maintained by the administration of the mush. If you have ideas of global aliases, suggest it to them and they will add them. Syntax: mail/alias Wizards: wizhelp wmail alias
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/anonymous

Command: mail/anon player=message mail/anon/send player=message mail/anon/forward <msg#> player=message mail/anon/reply <msg#>=message The anon[ymous] switch is used in junction with the /send, /forward, or /reply switches (or normal sending) to ANONYMOUSLY send the mail message to the player. Wizards are except from receiving anonymous mail due to security issues. Attempting to forward anonymous mail shows the original message being 'anonymous'. Attempting to reply to an anonymous mail will reply to the 'anonymous' player, while that player still receives the message. If you use the line editor, you can use -~ to send anonymously instead of -- which would normally send the mail. See Also: mail send, mail reply, mail forward
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/autofor

Command: mail/autofor <player-name> mail/autofor +off Autoforwarding is used to autoforward mail that you would normally get to another player. This is handy in the event that you have multiple players and wish to have mail all catagorized to a central player. All forwarded mail is sent as from the original sender, not from the player it was forwarded from. Autoforwarding can only be forwarded on a one-time basis. It is not recursive. So in otherwords, you can not forward mail forwarded to you. To remove an autoforwarding use the command: mail/autofor +off Mail that is autoforwarded will show up to the user sending you mail where it got autoforwarded to. See Also: mail lock, mail share
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/check

Command: mail/check <target>=<#> If someone has set up her mailbox to be shared with you, you can use this command to read a particular message from the target's mailbox. Example: > mail/check tinyfriend=4 (read tinyfriend's message #4) See Also: mail read, mail number, mail share
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/delete

Command: mail/delete This command will delete all your marked messages in all your folders. See Also: mark, unmark, recall, save
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/forward

Command: mail/forward <msg #> [@|^]<list> [=[<subject>//]<additional text>] Forward a mail message to someone. Note that you do not have to include your own message, which is appended to the bottom of the message. The message number and the address list are separated by a space. For the format of the address list, see the help on the send sub-command (help mail send). You can only forward messages in the current folder. Examples: > mail/forward 3 myfriend > mail/forward 2 &friendlist=Weird!!!//What do you think of this? > mail/forward 12 @friend1 #12345 friend2=Can you believe this?! Note: If you have the BRANDY_MAIL @toggle set, the syntax would be this: > mail/forward 3 myfriend > mail/forward 2 &friendlist=My Subject > mail/forward 12 @friend1 #12345 friend2=This is a subject You'd then use '-' for additional text and '--' to send the mail. See Also: mail reply, mail send
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/lock

Command: mail/lock <key> You can lock your mailbox so that only certain people can (or cannot) send you mail. The key is the same as for any other lock. Type: 'help @lock keys' for a list of the keys you may use. To unlock, use a blank key. IE: mail/lock (this will unlock your mail lock) Examples: > mail/lock tinyspouse (this locks to just tinyspouse) > mail/lock !tinyjerk (this locks against tinyjerk) > mail/lock (this removes your mail lock) The attribute it sets on you is 'MailLock' and is set like a normal lock. See Also: mail reject, mail recall
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/mark

Command: mail/mark <#>|all|<*player> This command allows you to mark messages for deletion. <#> indicates a specific message to be marked. To delete more than one message by message number, separate the message numbers by spaces. Specify "all" to mark all messages. Specify a person by name or db reference # to mark all messages from that player. You can only mark messages in the current folder. You would add /save as a switch to mark a message for being saved instead of marking it for deletion. See 'help mail save' for more. Examples: > mail/mark 1 (mark message 1 for deletion) > mail/mark 1 5 8 (mark messages 1, 5, and 8 for deletion) > mail/mark all (mark all your messages for deletion) > mail/mark *tinypal (mark messages from player 'tinypal' for deletion) > mail/mark #12345 (mark messages from player #12345 for deletion) > mail/mark 1-5 8 9 (mark messages 1 through 5, 8, and 9 for deletion) See Also: mail unmark, mail delete, mail status, mail save
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/mark/save

Command: mail/mark/save <range> mail/unmark <range> (notice, you do not use /save with this) The save switch is used in junction with the MARK switch. When used, this will mark a mail message as SAVED and any autodeletion will not remove the mail. Please note that there is a maximum number of saved messages available that you can use and once reached, you are unable to save new ones w/o removing one of your prior ones. To unmark the message you may either use mail/mark (without a save) or mail/unmark. Saved mail shows up with a 'S' by the flag. See Also: mail mark
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/next

Command: mail/next This option will automatically view the next mail message from the one you last read. For example, if you typed: mail 1 you would read mail message #1 (if you had mail) If you typed: mail/next you would read mail message #2 (if you had that number of messages) Note: If you add a '-' after next (i.e. mail/next -) it will read the previous message. See Also: mail status, mail zap, mail read
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/number

Command: mail/number <target>=# This command is similar to the status command. If someone has set up his mailbox to be shared with you, you can use this command to see the status of the target's mailbox. As with the status command, the # here is optional. If it is given (in this case the second argument), it will have the same effect as it would on the status command. Examples: > mail/number tinyspouse (list all of tinyspouses mail [if you pass lock]) > mail/number tinypal=2 (list just message 2 of tinyspouses mail) See Also: mail status, mail check, mail page, mail share
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/page

Command: mail/page <value> This sub-command sets the length of your pages. When you specify a page number in the status and number sub-commands, the pages are each composed of as many mail message headers as you set with the page sub-command. A value of 0 means to not divide the status and number into separate pages (i.e. all message headers are displayed on a single page). Examples: > mail/page 20 > mail/status p1 > mail/status p2 See Also: mail status, mail number, mail quick
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/password

Command: mail/password +set=<password> mail/password <password> mail/password +set The first version of the password sub-command sets your password for mail access. Once you set your password, you must use the second form of the password sub-command every time you connect to this mud in order to access your mail. Note that you only have to enter your mail password once per login session. If you have not set a mail password, you do not need to enter a password at all to access your mail. To clear the password, use the +set format with a blank password. Your mail password is separate from your login password. Examples: > mail/password +set=appleorange (set mail password) > mail/password appleorrange (enter password to access mail) > mail/password +set (remove password) See Also: mail share, mail lock, mail autofor
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/previous

Command: mail/next - Yes, you put a hyphen after the next. This will in effect view the previous mail message from the one you last read. For example, if you typed: mail 5 You would read mail message #5 (if you had mail) If you typed: mail/next - You would read mail message #4 See Also: mail next, mail zap
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/quick

Command: mail/quick [<folder>] Get a quick summary of how many new, unread, old, and marked messages in the current folder. Also reports the current folder. You may specify an optional folder to get quick a quick summary of that particular mail folder. The /quick switch is optional for this command and you can just type 'mail' standalone. The /quick switch is required if you specify a folder. See Also: mail status, mail
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/quota

Command: mail/quota Check how many mail messages are in your mailbox, as well as the maximum amount of mail messages you are allowed to store in your mailbox. It will also display the total number of saved messages you are allowed and the total number of saved messages you currently have used. See Also: quick, status Wizards: wizhelp wmail size
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/read

Command: mail[/read] <msg #|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N> mail/read/save <msg #|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N> Read a mail message. You can specify the message number, or to read the first new or unread mail message. Check help on the status sub-command (wizhelp mail status)for information on how to see mail headers. The /READ switch is optional. The optional /save switch when used in junction with the /read switch will output the mail in a standard EMail format (MBOX) which you can then save to file and load in your favorite email program (mutt, pine, elm, outlook, thunderbird, and so forth). You would just import the file as an MBOX formatted file. Please refer to your mail program on how to read in this mail format. Optional arguments to 'mail/read[/save]' is as follows: mail[/read] +all - read ALL your messages (spammy) mail[/read] new - read first new message mail[/read] nall - read ALL new messages mail[/read] unread - read first unread message mail[/read] uall - read ALL unread messages mail[/read] ball - read ALL new AND unread messages mail[/read] X-Y - read messages starting at 'X' and until 'Y' mail[/read] # - read specified mail message number Examples: > mail/read 2 > mail 10 > mail/read new > mail new > mail/read unread > mail/read 3-7 > mail 2-8 > mail unread See Also: mail status, mail delete, mail mark, mail next, mail zap, mail unmark, mail save, mail new, mail unread, mail nall, mail ball, mail uall
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/read/save

Command: mail[/read] <msg #|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N> mail/read/save <msg #|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N> Read a mail message. You can specify the message number, or to read the first new or unread mail message. Check help on the status sub-command (wizhelp mail status)for information on how to see mail headers. The /READ switch is optional. The optional /save switch when used in junction with the /read switch will output the mail in a standard EMail format (MBOX) which you can then save to file and load in your favorite email program (mutt, pine, elm, outlook, thunderbird, and so forth). You would just import the file as an MBOX formatted file. Please refer to your mail program on how to read in this mail format. Optional arguments to 'mail/read[/save]' is as follows: mail[/read] +all - read ALL your messages (spammy) mail[/read] new - read first new message mail[/read] nall - read ALL new messages mail[/read] unread - read first unread message mail[/read] uall - read ALL unread messages mail[/read] ball - read ALL new AND unread messages mail[/read] X-Y - read messages starting at 'X' and until 'Y' mail[/read] # - read specified mail message number Examples: > mail/read 2 > mail 10 > mail/read new > mail new > mail/read unread > mail/read 3-7 > mail 2-8 > mail unread See Also: mail status, mail delete, mail mark, mail next, mail zap, mail unmark, mail save, mail new, mail unread, mail nall, mail ball, mail uall
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/recall

Command: mail/recall [ <#>|+all|*<player> [=<player>|+all] ] mail/recall <various options> This command will let you recall (IE: delete) unread, unmarked messages that you have sent to other players. It allows you you to either list all messages that you have sent that you can currently recall, view a specified message that you sent that can be recalled, and optionally recall from a single or multiple users or recall all messages. To view all messages that you can recall: mail/recall This will display something like this: Msg #: 1 To: Seawolf Wizard Msg #: 8 To: Wizard George Freddie Msg #: 10 To: TwinkMan Mail: Done This will show mail you have sent that can still be recalled. The Msg# may skip numbers if those messages have been previously read and can no longer be recalled. *NOTE* You may specify a player with '*playername' to limit the search on both 'mail/recall' and 'mail/recall/all'. { To continue [with examples], please type: help mail recall2 }
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/reject

Command: mail/reject <msg> mail/reject +list mail/reject Will set the message sent when a player attempts to send a mail message to someone who has that player locked from mailing them. This works similar to the @reject for pages. To see the current reject message use the +list option. To clear the message, do mail/reject without a message. Use the /lock switch to mail to establish a mail lock. Examples: > mail/reject I don't want you to mail me anymore. Nayh! > mail/reject > mail/reject +list See Also: mail lock
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/reply

Command: mail/reply [@|^]<msg #>[*]=[<subject>//]<message>. Reply to a mail message with your own message. The @, ^, and * are optional to preface or follow the message number. You can only reply to messages in the current folder. You may also specify an optional subject. To reply to all recipients of the mail message, in addition to the sender: -preface the message number with @ for all recipients of your reply to appear in the 'To' line. -preface the message number with ^ for all recipients to see only their own name in the 'To' line (i.e. not see who else received the reply). This is the default. To include the original message in your reply: -follow the message number with *. Examples: > mail/reply 2=Sure, I'll come to the party. > mail/reply 1*=What did you mean? > mail/reply @12=Why don't we all get together tomorrow? > mail/reply ^9*=I'm not sure if we should build that. Note: If you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL, instead of <message> it would be your subject. Then you'd use '-' for additional text and '--' to send. See Also: mail forward, mail send
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/save

Command: mail/mark/save <range> mail/unmark <range> (notice, you do not use /save with this) The save switch is used in junction with the MARK switch. When used, this will mark a mail message as SAVED and any autodeletion will not remove the mail. Please note that there is a maximum number of saved messages available that you can use and once reached, you are unable to save new ones w/o removing one of your prior ones. To unmark the message you may either use mail/mark (without a save) or mail/unmark. Saved mail shows up with a 'S' by the flag. See Also: mail mark
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/save/read

Command: mail[/read] <msg #|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N> mail/read/save <msg #|new|unread|nall|uall|ball|1-N> Read a mail message. You can specify the message number, or to read the first new or unread mail message. Check help on the status sub-command (wizhelp mail status)for information on how to see mail headers. The /READ switch is optional. The optional /save switch when used in junction with the /read switch will output the mail in a standard EMail format (MBOX) which you can then save to file and load in your favorite email program (mutt, pine, elm, outlook, thunderbird, and so forth). You would just import the file as an MBOX formatted file. Please refer to your mail program on how to read in this mail format. Optional arguments to 'mail/read[/save]' is as follows: mail[/read] +all - read ALL your messages (spammy) mail[/read] new - read first new message mail[/read] nall - read ALL new messages mail[/read] unread - read first unread message mail[/read] uall - read ALL unread messages mail[/read] ball - read ALL new AND unread messages mail[/read] X-Y - read messages starting at 'X' and until 'Y' mail[/read] # - read specified mail message number Examples: > mail/read 2 > mail 10 > mail/read new > mail new > mail/read unread > mail/read 3-7 > mail 2-8 > mail unread See Also: mail status, mail delete, mail mark, mail next, mail zap, mail unmark, mail save, mail new, mail unread, mail nall, mail ball, mail uall
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/send

Command: mail/send [@]<address list>=[<subject>//]<message> The address list can contain any number of recipients (up to the mush buffer limit) and can be one of the following: A player name A player number prefixed by a dbrief# A mail alias attribute located on the player prefixed by a & (this is just an attribute on yourself with a list of players) A global mail alias attribute prefixed by a +. A mail alias attribute location on optional target prefixed by a ~ character. This is evaluated like get_eval(). The different elements in the address list need to be separated by spaces. If you include the optional '@', all recipients of a mail message will see the complete list of recipients. (This will show up as a 'CC' list). To give an optional subject, enter text you want as a subject then separate that from the rest of the message with two /'s. (IE: // ) There is an exception to the '@'. Check @list options, if the To: is automatically added, the '@' character's behavior is reversed. You can break up mail with either spaces OR commas and duplicates are automatically stripped out. { help mail send2 for more, or help mail send examples for examples }
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/share

Command: mail/share <key> Share lets you give access to your mailbox for other players who pass the lock. The key is a standard boolean lock expression, as documented in 'help @lock keys'. Any player who passes the lock may do the /number and /check sub-commands on your mailbox. If you do not have a share lock set on your mail, this is the same as if nobody can pass the share lock. To clear the lock, enter a blank expression. If you set a folder/share, players who pass the mail/share lock can only see the folder you specify. Examples: > mail/share *tinyspouse (allows tinyspouse into your mail) > mail/share *tinyspouse | *tinypal (allows tinyspouse and tinypal) > mail/share (removes the sharelock) The attribute is 'ShareLock' on yourself. See Also: mail number, mail check, mail folders, mail folder, mail share
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/status

Command: mail/status [[p#] [*player] [#-#] [U/N/B/O/M/S] [/SUBJECT]] This will print out a list of the message headers in the current folder for which the player has mail. This will also show the current folder. The p# argument (where # is an integer) will print out the specified page of message headers if the user has his/her paging value set. The page is determined from the paging value entered with the page command which represents the number of messages on a page. If the user has no paging value set, entering a page number on this command will have no effect. If the user has a paging value set and enters 0 for the page number, the user will get all message headers without any page breaks. Check out help on 'mail page' to see how to set your paging value. The '*player' option will show all mail sent to you from the given player, and the #-# is a range of messages you would like to see. The letters U, N, B, O, M, and S are the special character representations for: (U)nread (N)ew (B)oth new and unread (O)ld (M)arked (for deletion) (S)aved The /SUBJECT option will do a search for mail matching '/SUBJECT' in the subject field. The string after the '/' tells what to search for. { To continue with examples, see 'help mail status2' }
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/unmark

Command: mail/unmark <#>|all (this works for saved messages as well) This command is similar to mark except that it unmarks messages. You may use mark and unmark to mark all but specific messages. You can only unmark messages in the current folder. You would use this to unmark SAVED messages as well. Examples: > mail/mark all > mail/unmark tinyspouse (These two commands in this order mark all but tinyspouse's messages.) > mail/mark tinypal > mail/unmark 2 5 (These two commands in this order mark all of tinypal's messages, except messages 2 and 5). > mail/unmark 1-5 (unmark messages 1 through 5) See Also: mail mark, mail delete, mail status, mail save
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/version

Command: mail/version this command will show the current version of the mailsystem.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write

Topic: mail writing Note: For help on creating new mail, please see 'help mail send' mail/write gives you the flexability of a line-editor within mail. There are various options with mail/write that you may use. Help is available on each of these topics. Topics: ADDING FORWARDING QUICKSENDING CMDLIST AUTONOTIFY EXAMPLES Write Functionality: - +edit +del +join +justify +split +insert +list +forward +reply +subject +forget +send +fedit +editall +feditall +cc +bcc +acc +proof Type: help mail write <option> for help on these topics/functionality.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +acc

Command: mail/write +acc=<player-list> The '+acc' subcommand is used to modify (add to) the target list of players the mail is going out to. Keep in mind, this ONLY works for sending or forwarding. This does *NOT* work for replies. This only works when you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL and when you start a message with 'mail player-list=subject' (or similiar). Example: > mail/write +acc=player1 player2 &myalias +globalalias Mail: New send player list stored. See Also: mail write +cc, mail write +bcc
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +bcc

Command: mail/write +bcc=<player-list> The '+bcc' subcommand is used to modify (add to) the target list and blind target list of players the mail is going out to. Keep in mind, this ONLY works for sending or forwarding. This does *NOT* work for replies. If 'bcc_hidden' is ENABLED, then whoever is in the +bcc list will _NOT_ see who the mail was sent to. If 'bcc_hidden' is DISABLED, then whoever is in the +bcc list WILL see who the mail was sent to, but no one outside the +bcc list will. In effect, bcc_hidden toggles the effect. Please check '@list options mail' for the current configuration. You may specify '!ALL' to clear the Bcc list without effecting the To list. This only works when you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL and when you start a message with 'mail player-list=subject' (or similiar). Example: > mail/write +bcc=player1 player2 &myalias +globalalias Mail: New send player list stored. See Also: mail write +cc, mail write +acc
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +cc

Command: mail/write +cc=<player-list> The '+cc' subcommand is used to replace (not modify!) the target list of players the mail is going out to. Keep in mind, this ONLY works for sending or forwarding. This does *NOT* work for replies. This only works when you are @toggled BRANDY_MAIL and when you start a message with 'mail player-list=subject' (or similiar). Example: > mail/write +cc=player1 player2 &myalias +globalalias ~evalalias Mail: New send player list stored. See Also: mail write +bcc, mail write +acc
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +del

Command: mail/write +del=<args> The '+del' subcommand to mail/write is used to delete a line of text. Examples: > mail/write A line of text Mail: Write message started. > -Another line of txt Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of text 2: Another line of txt ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +del=1 Mail: Write line deleted. > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: Another line of txt ------------------------------------------------------------------------- Note: You can't delete line #1 if that's the only line there is. Use mail/write +forget to remove it. See Also: mail write +edit, mail write +split, mail write +forget
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +edit

Command: mail/write +edit <line>=<old>,<new> The '+edit' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit a line of text. This only edits the FIRST occurance of text in the line. Examples: > mail/write A line of text Mail: Write message started. > -Another line of txt Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of text 2: Another line of txt ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +edit 2=txt,text Mail: +edit done. > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of text 2: Another line of text ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +del, mail write +join, mail write +justify
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +editall

Command: mail/write +editall=<old>,<new> The '+editall' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit ALL lines of text. This only edits the FIRST occurance of text in the lines. Examples: > mail/write A line of txt txt Mail: Write message started. > -Another line of txt txt Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of txt 2: Another line of txt ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +editall=txt,text Mail: +editall done (2 lines edited) > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of text txt 2: Another line of text txt ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +feditall, mail write +edit, mail write +fedit
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +fedit

Command: mail/write +fedit <line>=<old>,<new> The '+fedit' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit a line of text. Unlike the '+edit' subcommand, this edits ALL occurances of the text in the line. Examples: > mail/write A line of text Mail: Write message started. > -Another line of txt Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of text 2: Another line of txt ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +fedit 2=txt,text Mail: +fedit done. > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of text 2: Another line of text ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +del, mail write +join, mail write +justify, mail write +fedit, mail write +editall, mail write +feditall
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +feditall

Command: mail/write +feditall=<old>,<new> The '+feditall' subcommand to mail/write is used to edit ALL lines of text. This edits ALL occurances of text in ALL the lines. Examples: > mail/write A line of txt txt Mail: Write message started. > -Another line of txt txt Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of txt 2: Another line of txt ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +feditall=txt,text Mail: +feditall done (2 lines edited) > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: A line of text text 2: Another line of text text ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +editall, mail write +edit, mail write +fedit
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +forget

Command: mail/write +forget The '+forget' subcommand to mail/write is used to purge the mail in progress effectively deleting all of the mail/write information. Examples: > mail/write Start of message Mail: Write message started. > -another line Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: 1: Start of message 2: another line > mail/write +forget Mail: Write message forgotten. > mail/write +list Mail: No write in progress. See Also: mail write +edit, mail write +del
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +forward

Command: mail/write +forward=<message number> <player-list> The '+forward' subcommand to mail/write is used to forward the mail in progress to the player list while including the specified message number from your mailbox. Examples: > mail/write TinyPlayer sent me this... what do you think? Mail: Write message started. > mail/status ------------------------------------------------------------------------- [0] ( 1) From: TinyPlayer <Mon Jan 1 01:01:01 2000> (1095 Bytes) Subj: Hey! ------------------------------------------------------------------------- Note: if the player 'TinyPlayer' was connected, they'd have a '*' before the 'From:'. i.e. *From: TinyPlayer > mail/write +forward=1 MyFriend Mail: Message sent to -> MyFriend See Also: mail write +reply, mail write quicksending, mail forward mail status
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +insert

Command: mail/write +insert=<args> The '+insert' subcommand to mail/write is used to insert a line before the specified line. Examples: > mail/write Start of mail Mail: Write message started. > -Third line Mail: Write line 2 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: Start of mail 2: Third line ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +insert=2,Second line Mail: Line inserted. > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: Start of mail 2: Second line 3: Third line ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +del, mail write +join
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +join

Command: mail/write +join=<args> The '+join' subcommand to mail/write is used to join two lines of text. Examples: > mail/write This is Mail: Write message started. > -This is the end of the line. Mail: Write line 2 added > -a test Mail: Write line 3 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: This is 2: This is the end of the line. 3: a test ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +join=1,3 Mail: Line joined. > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: This is a test 2: This is the end of the line. ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +del, mail write +split
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +justify

Command: mail/write +justify=<args> The '+justify' subcommand to mail/write is used to justify the line. Valid options are (l)eft, (c)enter, or (r)ight for justification. Examples: > mail/write This is a test Mail: Write message started. > -This is the end of the line. Mail: Write line 2 added > -ok, I lied. Mail: Write line 3 added > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: This is a test 2: This is the end of the line. 3: ok, I lied. ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +justify=1,c Mail: Line justified. > mail/write +justify=2,r Mail: Line justified. > mail/write +list ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: This is a test 2: This is the end of the line. 3: ok, I lied. ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +join, mail write +del
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +list

Command: mail/write +list [=<args>] The '+list' subcommand to mail/write is used to list the lines of your write message. Examples: > mail/write +list Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: Line one 2: Line two 3: Line three ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +list=2 Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 2: Line two 3: Line three ------------------------------------------------------------------------- > mail/write +list=1,2 Mail: Your write message is: ------------------------------------------------------------------------- 1: Line one 2: Line two ------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +forget, mail write +send
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +proof

Command: mail/write +proof The '+proof' subcommand to mail/write is used to give you a 'snapshot' of approximately what the mail will look like when it is sent out. This does not show any text that will be included in forwarded or replied to mail if you chose the options to include original text. Examples: > mail/write This is some text Mail: Write message started. > mail/write +proof --------------------------------------------------------------------------- Message In Progress Status: EDITING From: You To: (empty list) Date/Time: Mon May 14 18:50:27 2011 Size: 18 Bytes Subject: (None) --------------------------------------------------------------------------- This is some text --------------------------------------------------------------------------- See Also: mail write +list, mail write
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

mail/write +reply

Command: mail/write +reply=<message number> The '+reply' subcommand to mail/write is used to reply to the specified message with the mail that is in progress. Examples: > mail/write Thanks for the mail.
