The list that is returned is sorted. If <delim> is specified, it (rather than a space) is used to separate items in the list. If <sep> is specified, it will be used (rather than a space) for the output separator for the list. If <sorttype> is specified, you may have a different sort than the default alphanumerical sort. (d)bref, (n)umeric, (f)loat, (a)lphanumeric. Example: > say setdiff(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep) You say, "baz foo" > say setdiff(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep,,-) You say, "baz-foo" See Also: setinter(), setunion(), sort(), listdiff()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SETINTER()

Function: setinter(<list1>, <list2>[, <delim> [, <sep> [, <sorttype>]]]) This function returns the intersection of two sets -- i.e., the elements that are in both <list1> and <list2>. The list that is returned is sorted. If <delim> is specified, it (rather than a space) is used to separate items in the list. If <sep> is specified, it will be used (rather than a space) for the output separator for the list. If <sorttype> is specified, you may have a different sort than the default alphanumerical sort. (d)bref, (n)umeric, (f)loat, (a)lphanumeric. Example: > say setinter(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep) You say, "bar gleep" > say setinter(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep,,-) You say, "bar-gleep" See Also: setdiff(), setunion(), sort(), listinter()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SETQ()

Function: setq(<register>,<string>[,<label>]) setq(<label>,<string>[,<label>) setq(!,<string>,<label>) setq(+,<string>,<label>) -- Penn Compatibility (if enabled via penn_setq admin param) setq(<label|register>,<string>) setq(+,<string>,<label>) setq(!,<string>,<label>) The setq() function is used to copy strings into local registers. It returns a null string; it is a purely "side effect" function. There are ten local registers, numbered 0 through 9. They are cleared at the start of each command. They are most useful for storing complex function evaluations which are used repeatedly within a single command. The local registers may be read via the r() function, and a common use of setq()/r() is to temporarily store the result of a complex evaluation whose result is needed more than once. setq() can be used to improve the readability of MUSH code, as well as to cut down the amount of time needed to do complex evaluations. If enhanced setq has been enabled at compiletime, you may use a-z as well. Enabling this in the code can cause some excess memory usage. Compiletime may also switch this functionality with SETQ_OLD(). Check @list options to see if it was. You may specify an optional label to assign the register to later call with r(). Labels can contain any character and must be 31 chars or less. You may then specify the label instead of the <number>. Using '!' for the number/label specifies to reuse the label OR assign a label to the next available register automatically. '+' will use the first unnamed AND unused register. '!' just uses the first unnamed register. If the label is 0-9 or a-z when using '+' or '!' it assumes you want the register set and not a label assigned. Example: > &TEST me=Test on [mudname()] at [time()]. > say [setq(0,u(TEST))]'[r(0)]' has length [strlen(r(0))]. You say "'Test on TestMUSH at Tue Feb 23 17:00:51 1993.' has length 45." > say [setq(0,u(TEST),test)][setq(test,Test: [u(test)])][r(0)] You say "Test: Test on TestMUSH at Tue Feb 23 17:00:51 1993" See Also: setr(), setr_old(), setq_old(), r(), nameq(), inc(), dec(), setqmatch(), SETQ_TEMPLATE
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SETQ_OLD()

Function: setq_old(<register>,<string>[,<label>]) setq_old(<label>,<string>[,<label>]) setq_old(!,<string>,<label>) setq_old(+,<string>,<label>) -- Penn Compatibility (if enabled via penn_setq admin param) setq_old(<label|register>,<string>) setq_old(+,<string>,<label>) setq_old(!,<string>,<label>) This functions exactly like setq(), except it is using the old MUSH method of evaluation. This tends to be less abraisive on braces and brackets. Please check @list options to see if SETQ_OLD and SETQ are switched at compiletime. You may specify an optional label to assign the register to later call with r(). Labels can contain any character and must be 31 chars or less. You may then specify the label instead of the <number>. Using '!' for the number/label specifies to reuse the label OR assign a label to the next available register automatically. '+' will use the first unnamed AND unused register. '!' just uses the first unnamed register. If the label is 0-9 or a-z when using '+' or '!' it assumes you want the register set and not a label assigned. See Also: setr_old(), setq(), setr(), nameq(), SETQ_TEMPLATE
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SETQ_TEMPLATES

You can specify 'templates' for setq registers to automatically have pre-defined labels for each individual object. This is done by setting a string in the attribute 'SETQ_TEMPLATE' on the object. The attribute should be in the format: <register>:<string> So an example would be: 0:foobar 1:xyzzy q:myqreg This would set a template on an object where it would preassign the label 'foobar' to register 0, 'xyzzy' to register 1, and 'myqreg' to register q. Note: These are only useful for the immediate calling $commands. They are not transversed through u() functions, @triggers, or other action based events. You may redefine these labels as you would normally with nameq(), setq(), or setr(). See Also: nameq(), setq(), setr()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SETQMATCH()

Function: setqmatch(<string>, <pattern>[,delim]) The setqmatch() function tries to match <pattern> against <string>. If it succeeds, it returns 1 and puts the text that matched each wildcard (up to ten) into successive setq registers. The first wildcard's match goes into register 0, the second into register 1, etc. (If it reaches '10' and there's more, dump the remaining into '10' if '10' is a '*' wildcard and not a '?' wildcard) If it fails, it returns 0. If optional delimiter of 'n' is specified, then it returns nothing for failures or successes. Default is 'y' for returning values. Example: > say setqmatch(This is a test, *test) -- [r(0)] You say "1 -- This is a " > say setqmatch(open the door hal, open * ???) -- [r(0)] -- [r(2)] You say "1 -- the door -- a" > say setqmatch(kow, wok) You say "0" > say setqmatch(kow, wok, n) You say "" See Also: listmatch(), match(), totmatch(), wildmatch(), setq()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SETR()

Function: setr(<register>,<string>[,<label>]) setr(<label>,<string>[,<label>]) setr(!,<string>,<label>) setr(+,<string>,<label>) -- Penn Compatibility (if enabled via penn_setq admin param) setr(<label|register>,<string>) setr(+,<string>,<label>) setr(!,<string>,<label>) The setr() function is used to copy strings into local registers. Unlike setq(), it returns its <string> argument. In all other respects it is identical to setq(). If enhanced setq has been enabled at compiletime, you may use a-z as well. Enabling this in the code can cause some excess memory usage. Compiletime may also switch this functionality with SETR_OLD(). Check @list options to see if it was. You may specify an optional label to assign the register to later call with r(). Labels can contain any character and must be 31 chars or less. You may then specify the label instead of the <number>. Using '!' for the number/label specifies to reuse the label OR assign a label to the next available register automatically. '+' will use the first unnamed AND unused register. '!' just uses the first unnamed register. If the label is 0-9 or a-z when using '+' or '!' it assumes you want the register set and not a label assigned. Example: > &TEST me=Test on [mudname()] at [time()]. > say '[setr(0,u(TEST))]' has length [strlen(r(0))]. You say "'Test on TestMUSH at Tue Feb 23 17:00:51 1993.' has length 45." See Also: setq(), setq_old(), setr_old(), r(), nameq(), inc(), dec(), setqmatch(), SETQ_TEMPLATE
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SETR_OLD()

Function: setr_old(<register>,<string>[,<label>]) setr_old(<label>,<string>[,<label>]) setr_old(!,<string>,<label>) setr_old(+,<string>,<label>) -- Penn Compatibility (if enabled via penn_setq admin param) setr_old(<label|register>,<string>) setr_old(+,<string>,<label>) setr_old(!,<string>,<label>) This functions exactly like setr(), except it is using the old MUSH method of evaluation. This tends to be less abraisive on braces and brackets. Please check @list options to see if SETR_OLD and SETR are switched at compiletime. You may specify an optional label to assign the register to later call with r(). Labels can contain any character and must be 31 chars or less. You may then specify the label instead of the <number>. Using '!' for the number/label specifies to reuse the label OR assign a label to the next available register automatically. '+' will use the first unnamed AND unused register. '!' just uses the first unnamed register. If the label is 0-9 or a-z when using '+' or '!' it assumes you want the register set and not a label assigned. See Also: setq_old(), setq(), setr(), nameq(), SETQ_TEMPLATE
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SETUNION()

Function: setunion(<list1>, <list2>[, <delim> [, <sep> [, <sorttype>]]]) This function returns the union of two sets -- i.e., all the elements of both <list1> and <list2>, minus any duplicate elements. Think of it as CAT() without duplicated words. The list returned is sorted. If <delim> is specified, it (rather than a space) is used to separate items in the list. If <sep> is specified, it will be used (rather than a space) for the output separator for the list. If <sorttype> is specified, you may have a different sort than the default alphanumerical sort. (d)bref, (n)umeric, (f)loat, (a)lphanumeric. Example: > say setunion(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep) You say, "bar baz foo gleep moof" > say setunion(foo baz gleep bar, bar moof gleep,,-) You say, "bar-baz-foo-gleep-moof" See Also: setdiff(), setinter(), sort(), listunion()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SHIFT()

Function: shift(<value>) shift() This function controls the values returned with %0-%9 (or v(0)-v(9)) with regards to u() attributes, functions or @functions. Each increment to shift will shift the values 10. So shift(1) will make %5 actually be the 15's argument, not the 5th. You can shift up to the max arguments currently allowed by the mush. The default is 30 total arguments, thus you can shift to the value '3'. If you do not specify an argument, it shows you what the current shift value is set to. This value resets itself for each pass through the queue (or by user-intervention). See Also: v()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

shl()

Function: shl(<number or string>,<count>) Performs a leftwards bit-shift on <number>, shifting it <count> times. This is equivalent to mul(<number>,pow(2,<count>), but much faster. This function also shifts left a given string <count> number of characters. Examples: > say shl(1,4) You say "16" > say shl(weird!!!,3) You say "rd!!!" See Also: shr(), rotl(), rotr()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SHOWFAILCMD

Flag: SHOWFAILCMD([f]) This flag, when set on an item, will return the appropiate @ufail messages (ufail, aufail, oufail), if there is a matching $command and the object is uselocked against you. If the object is set SHOWFAILCMD in addition to STOP, then the error is showed appropiately and all command processing is stopped at that point as well. See Also: @ufail, @fail
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

shr()

Function: shr(<number or string>,<count>) Performs a rightwards bit-shift on <number>, shifting it <count> times. This is equivalent to div(<number>,pow(2,<count>), but much faster. Function: case(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>]...[,<dflt>]). This function also shifts right a given string <count> number of characters. Examples: > say shr(16,3) You say "2" > say shr(weird!!!,4) You say "weir" See Also: shl(), rotl(), rotr()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

shuffle()

Function: shuffle(<string> [,<delim> [,<output sep>]]) Returns the string randomly 'shuffled' or mixed up with regards to order. You may specify an optional delimiter instead of the default 'space' as well as an optional filler. Example: > say shuffle(This is a test) You say "This a is test" (separator is a space ' ') > say shuffle(This is a test) You say "a test This is" > say shuffle(This@is@a@test,@) You say "is@a@This@test" (separator is a '@') > say shuffle(This@is@a@test,@,|) You say "This|test|a|is" (separator is '@', filler is '|') See Also: rand(), scramble(), sort(), setdiff(), setinter(), setunion()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

side effect functions

Function Lists: Side Effect Functions. clone() - Clones an object. create() - Creates an object. destroy() - Destroys an object. dig() - Creates a room object. emit() - Emits a string to your location. lemit() - Like emit(), but finds the outermost room of your location. link() - Links an object to another. list() - Like iter(), but is buffer limit safe. lock() - Sets a specified lock on an object. name() - Sets the name of an object. nameq() - (Re)names setq variables with a new label. npemit() - Like pemit(), but will not strip spaces. oemit() - Like emit(), but will omit a specified target. open() - Opens an exit. parent() - Parents an object to another. pemit() - Emits a string to a list of targets. r() - Accesses local registers, and outputs its contents. remit() - Emits text to a specified room. rset() - Like set(), but returns the string that is set. ruler() - Display a ruler outline of contents of an attribute. rxlevel() - Sets or unsets a reality receive level for an object. set() - Sets an attribute on an object. setq() - Copies a string into a local register. setq_old() - Like setq(), but with old-style MUSH functionality. setr() - Like setq(), but also displays the string. setr_old() - Like setr(), but with old-style MUSH functionality. tel() - Teleports an object to a location. toggle() - Toggles a toggle on an object. totemset() - Set/remove a @totem on a target. txlevel() - Sets or unsets a reality transmit level for an object. wipe() - Wipes attribute(s) from object. zemit() - Emits a string to every room of a zone. sqlite_query() - SQL Lite database query. sql() - MySQL database query. sqlescape() - MySQL escape driven query. sqlon() - MySQL database enabler. sqloff() - MySQL database deabler.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SIDEEFFECTS

RhostMUSH supports side-effect functions. This has to be enabled by the site owner before they can be used. In addition, due to the many security issues that arise from using side-effects, before the function is accessable, it must be set SIDEFX. Please check @list options to see if side effects are enabled and what side effects are enabled of the list. list(), being relatively harmless in how it's coded, is omitted from the restrictions found with normal side-effects. MUX and PENN style sideeffects are both supported. Support for the force(), trigger() and wait() functions found in TinyMUSH 3.0 will NOT be supported ever. They're silly functions to add and the security issues involved with these functions are too large to ignore. NOTE: Side-effects are generally frowned upon and should not be used at all. This was only done for compatibility. Type '@list options' to see what side-effects are currently in effect. MUX sideeffects supported: SET, CREATE, LINK, PEMIT, TEL, LIST, OEMIT, PARENT, and DESTROY PENN sideeffects supported: SET, CREATE, LINK, PEMIT, TEL, DIG, OPEN, EMIT, OEMIT, CLONE, PARENT, LOCK, LEMIT, REMIT, WIPE, ZEMIT, NAME, and LSET OTHER sideeffects supported: DESTROY, TOGGLE, TXLEVEL, RXLEVEL, RSET, and MOVE The following sideeffects are handled by the database portion as a separate entity. DB sideeffects supported: SQLITE_QUERY, SQL, SQLON, SQLOFF, SQLESCAPE, SQLPING Help is available on MUX, PENN and OTHER side-effects by name.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SIDEFX

Flag: SIDEFX([s]) If set on the target, the target is gained the ability to be able to execute (and use) side-effects. Without this flag, it is impossible to use side-effects. Please check '@list options' to see what side-effects (if any) are enabled on the RhostMUSH you're on and if you have access to them.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SIGN()

Function: sign(<number>) Returns -1, 0, or 1 depending on whether its argument is negative, zero, or positive (respectively). Example: > say sign(-4) You say "-1" > say sign(4) You say "1" > say sign(0) You say "0" > say sign(-1) You say "-1" See Also: abs()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SIN()

Function: sin(<number> [,<units>]) Returns the sine of <number>, expressed in radians. You may specify <units> which are either (r)adians, (g)radians, or (d)egrees. (r)adians are the default. Examples: > say sin(0) You say "0" > say sin(fdiv(pi(),2)) You say "1" > say sin(fdiv(pi(),4)) You say "0.707107" > say sin(fdiv(pi(),6)) You say "0.5" See Also: acos(), asin(), atan(), atan2(), cos(), pi(), tan(), ctu(), sinh(), cosh(), tanh()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SINGLETHREADING

You can accomplish 'single-threading' $commands by setting the attribute on the object SINGLETHREAD. Once set, you must have at the end of the processing a way to set the attribute !NO_COMMAND, else that $command will no longer be executable until the attribute's NO_COMMAND flag is removed. You may globally set the attribute SINGLETHREAD as well.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SINGLETIME()

Function: singletime(<seconds>) This function converts seconds to a single time element which is the lowest approximation to the given number of <seconds>. The following letters are relevant: s - second d - day y - year e - epoch m - minute w - week C - century h - hour M - month a - annum(Millennium) Note: an epoch is 1 million years or more. Example: > say singletime(45) You say "45s" > say singletime(12345) You say "3h" > say singletime(123456) You say "1d" Related Topics: secs(), time(), timefmt()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SINH()

Function: sinh(<number> [,<units>]) Returns the hyperbolic sine of <number>, expressed in radians. You may specify <units> which are either (r)adians, (g)radians, or (d)egrees. (r)adians are the default. Examples: > say sinh(0) You say "0" > say sinh(fdiv(pi(),2)) You say "2.301298" > say sinh(fdiv(pi(),4)) You say "0.868671" > say sinh(fdiv(pi(),6)) You say "0.547854" See Also: acos(), asin(), atan(), atan2(), cos(), pi(), tan(), ctu(), cosh(), tanh(), sin()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SLAVE

Flag: SLAVE(x) If set on a player, neither the player nor any of his objects may perform any commands that change the database. Some sites may restrict additional commands. This flag may only be set or cleared by wizards. See Also: FUBAR
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

smell

Command: smell [<object>] Displays the smells of <object>, or the location you're in if you don't specify an object. Specifying object as <name> or #<dbref> or 'me' or 'here' is legal. You can also use smell to smell objects held by other people. Just use 'smell <person>'s <object>'. See Also: look, touch, taste, listen, @ssmell, @sasmell, @sosmell
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SORT()

Function: sort(<list>[, <sort type>[, <delim> [, <sep>]]]) * Takes a list of words, numbers, or dbref, and sorts them into ascending order. Lexicographic order is used for words, and numeric order is used for numbers and dbrefs. * <sort type> may be used to specify the type of sort to perform (use d for dbref, n for integer numeric, f for floating numeric, and a for alphanumeric). If omitted or left blank, the sort() function will automatically determine the type of sort to perform. * If <delim> is specified, it (rather than a space) is used to separate items in the list. You may specify an alternate delimiter without specifying a sort type by passing a null <sort type> parameter. * If <sep> is specified, it (rather than a space) is used to separate items in the output. Examples: > say sort(This is a test) You say "This a is test" > say sort(98 99 100 101) You say "98 99 100 102" > say sort(foo-bar-bletch,,-) You say "bar-bletch-foo" > say sort(foo-bar-bletch,,-,+) You say "bar+bletch+foo" See Also: sortby(), munge(), map(), setinter(), setunion(), setdiff(), sortlist()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SORTBY()

Function: sortby([<obj>/]<attrib>,<list>[,<delim> [,<sep>]]) This sorts an arbitrary list according to the u-function <obj>/<attrib>. This u-function should compare two arbitrary elements, %0 and %1, and return zero (equal), a negative integer (element 1 is less than element 2) or a positive integer (element 1 is greater than element 2). A simple example, which imitates a normal alphabetic sort: > &ALPHASORT test=[comp(%0,%1)] > say [sortby(test/ALPHASORT,foo bar baz)] You say "bar baz foo" A slightly more complicated sort. #1 is "God", #2 is "Amby", "#3" is "Bob": > &NAMESORT me=[comp(name(%0),name(%1))] > say [sortby(NAMESORT,#1 #2 #3)] You say "#2 #3 #1" Warning: the function invocation limit applies to this function. If this limit is exceeded, the function will fail _silently_. List and function sizes should be kept reasonable. See Also: sort(), munge(), map(), setinter(), setunion(), setdiff()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SORTLIST()

Function: sortlist(<order>, <sep>[;<osep>], <list1>, <list2>, [...,<listN>]) This function takes 2 or more lists and chooses from each sample the max or min value based on the sorting value type. The <order> must have as the first character a + for maxsort or a - for minsort. If you do not specify a sort type after the +/- or if the value is invalid, it assumes alphanum. You may specify a seperator of <sep> for the elements in the list. This can only be one character. If part of the <sep> value is a semicolon followed by a string, it will take the first char as the <sep> value and anything after the semi-colon (;) as the <osep> output seperator for the list. The <osep> may be more than one character. An example is '%b;FOO' where '%b' (a space) would be the <sep> value, and 'FOO' would be the <osep> value. The lists may be unequal lists. The following <order> types are allowed: +a -- (default) sort alphanumerically by maximum value -a -- (default) sort alphanumerically by minimum value +n -- sort integers numerically by maximum value -n -- sort integers numerically by minimum value +f -- sort floating numerically by maximum value -f -- sort floating numerically by minimum value +d -- sort dbref#'s numerically by maximum valid dbref# (#-1 if invalid) -d -- sort dbref#'s numerically by minimum valid dbref# (#-1 if invalid) +/-m -- merge all the lists into a single list (+ or - does same thing) +/-m| -- same as above, but anything after the '|' will be taken as the output delimiter between elements in each <list>. With the dbref# sort, any invalid dbref# is assigned the value #-1. If all arguments in that list order are all invalid, #-1 will be seen for the value. { see 'help sortlist2' for examples }
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SORTLIST2

(CONTINUED) Function: sortlist(<order>, <sep>[;<osep>], <list1>, <list2>, [...,<listN>]) Examples: > say sortlist(+n,,1 2 3,10 0 20, 0 0 0) You say "10 2 20" > say sortlist(-n,,1 2 3,10 0 20, -100 100 200) You say "-100 0 3" > say sortlist(+n,:,1:2:3,5:6:7,4:4:4,0:9:20) You say "5:9:20" > say sortlist(+f,,1.2 2.5 3.3,1.3 2.4 -1.2) You say "1.3 2.5 3.3" > say sortlist(+d,,#1 #2 #3,#10 #0 #20 #3735 #100 #200 #333,#-1 #3 #3735) (Note: #3735 in this example is a Garbage/Recover/Non-Existant dbref#) You say "#10 #3 #20 #-1 #100 #200 #333" > say sortlist(+m,,a b c d e,1 2 3 4 5,v w x y z) You say "a1v b2w c3x d4y e5z" > say sortlist(+m|++,,a b c d e,1 2 3 4 5,v w x y z) You say "a++1++v b++2++w c++3++x d++4++y e++5++z" > say sortlist(+m|++,%b;@,a b c d e,1 2 3 4 5,v w x y z) You say "a++1++v@b++2++w@c++3++x@d++4++y@e++5++z" See Also: sort(), munge(), map(), setinter(), setunion(), setdiff(), listinter(), listunion(), listdiff()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SOUNDEX()

Function: soundex(<word>) The soundex function returns the soundex pattern for a word. A soundex pattern represents the sound of the word, and similar sounding words should have the same soundex pattern. Soundex patterns consist of an uppercase letter and 3 digits. Example: > think soundex(foobar) F160 For details of how the algorithm works, see help soundex2 See Also: soundlike()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SOUNDEX2

Here's how the soundex algorithm works: 1. The first letter of the soundex code is the first letter of the word (exception: words starting with PH get a soundex starting with F) 2. Each remaining letter is converted to a number: vowels, h, w, y ---------> 0 b, p, f, v --------------> 1 c, g, j, k, q, s, x, z --> 2 d, t --------------------> 3 l -----------------------> 4 m, n --------------------> 5 r -----------------------> 6 At this stage, "foobar" is "F00106" 3. Strings of the same number are condensed. "F0106" 4. All 0's are removed, because vowels are much less important than consonants in distinguishing words. "F16" 5. The string is padded with 0's or truncated to 4 characters. "F160" That's it. It's not foolproof (enough = "E520", enuf = "E510") but it works pretty well. :) Help borrowed from Penn with permission.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SOUNDLIKE()

Function: soundlike(<word>,<word>) Function: soundslike(<word>,<word>) (aliased) The soundslike function returns 1 if the two words have the same soundex code (see help soundex() for information), which means, in general, if they sound alike. For example: Examples: > think soundlike(robin,robbyn) 1 > think soundlike(robin,roebuck) 0 See Also: soundex() Help borrowed from Penn with permission.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SOUNDSLIKE()

Function: soundslike(<word>,<word>) (aliased) Function: soundlike(<word>,<word>) The soundslike function returns 1 if the two words have the same soundex code (see help soundex() for information), which means, in general, if they sound alike. For example: Examples: > think soundslike(robin,robbyn) 1 > think soundslike(robin,roebuck) 0 See Also: soundex() Help borrowed from Penn with permission.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SPACE()

Function: space(<count>) Returns the number of indicated spaces. If <count> is missing, negative, or cannot be converted to a number, one space is returned. This function is useful when you want to pass a single space (or more than one) as a function to an argument, because normally leading and trailing spaces are stripped from function arguments. Examples: > say space(4) You say " " > say edit(Foo bar bletch, space(), X) You say "FooXbarXbletch" See Also: repeat(), SUBSTITUTIONS
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SPEAK()

See 'help parsestr()'
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SPECIAL CHARACTERS

Topic: special characters There are characters considered 'special' based on the situation where they are used in mush. They usually do not have a global meaning for these cases, but only in special situations. $ - Specify the start of a command, or used in regexp matching. ^ - Specify the start of a listen, or used in regexp matching. \ - Escape character to escape the next character in a string. % - substitution character. Also used for the ansi-markup. , - function separation character to separate arguments to functions. ; - command seperation character to separate commands in a list. () - used in functions to denote start and end of a function call. [] - also used in functions to help with function separation calls. {} - a method to string together commands, strings, lists, or similar into a single command or call. & - the start of an attribute set command. @ - the start of most general built in commands or attribute calls. | - used to break out of @program and execute an outside command ! - used to break out of the current @door and execute a command to the previous calling mush. # - Specify the start of a dbref# * - Specify a long-distance lookup of a player Some functions and commands also have unique one-off use of characters or strings for special purposes as well, and this document will not cover those cases. See Also: escape(), search()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SPEECH_PREFIX

Topic: special attributes These attributes are settable with &SPEECH_PREFIX and &SPEECH_SUFFIX. They are pre and post handlers for the say and pose commands which will be triggered upon these commands being issued. These will only evaluate substitutions and will not evaluate functions. If these attributes are set NO_COMMAND they will not return any message. See Also: say, pose, ", :, ;
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SPEECH_SUFFIX

Topic: special attributes These attributes are settable with &SPEECH_PREFIX and &SPEECH_SUFFIX. They are pre and post handlers for the say and pose commands which will be triggered upon these commands being issued. These will only evaluate substitutions and will not evaluate functions. If these attributes are set NO_COMMAND they will not return any message. See Also: say, pose, ", :, ;
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SPELLNUM()

Function: spellnum(<number> [,<key>]) This function, when fed a number (decimal or floating point) will return the long name of the number (or in other wordes, the number in words). A 'key' of 1 specifies the ordinal number instead of the pure numeric. Ergo, 'tenth' instead of 'ten' or 'first' instead of 'one'. Ordinals do not work with decimal notation and will be ignored. Examples: > say spellnum(10) You say "ten" > say spellnum(10,1) You say "tenth" > say spellnum(1) You say "one" > say spellnum(1,1) You say "first" > say spellnum(1010) You say "one thousand ten" See Also: strmath()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SPLICE()

Function: splice(<list1>, <list2>, <word>[, <delim> [, <sep> ]]) This function splices <list1> and <list2> together. <list1> and <list2> are space-separated lists of words If a word in <list1> is the same as <word>, it is replaced by the word in the corresponding position in <list2>. Both lists must have the same number of words. <delim> may be used to specify a delimiter other than a space. <sep> may be used to specify an output separator other than a space. Example: > say splice(foo bar baz,eek moof gleep,bar) You say, "foo moof baz" > say splice(foo bar baz,eek moof gleep,bar,,-) You say, "foo-moof-baz" See Also: merge()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SPOOFING

Topic: SPOOFING Spoofing is the act of making other players think that a person said or did something that they did not. This is very easy to accomplish, and has some good effects, which is why it is allowed. Note that the NOSPOOF flag allows players to see exactly who is spoofing what. Be warned, wizards are rumored to have ways to find those who spoof them. Example: ... From TinyJerk's perspective ... > @emit Wizard is a jerk! Wizard is a jerk. ... From Wizard's perspective, Wizard is set NO_SPOOF ... [TinyJerk(#226)] Wizard is a jerk! > @boot tinyjerk You booted TinyJerk off! TinyJerk has disconnected. 1 connection closed. ... TinyJerk's perspective again ... Wizard gently shows you the door. *** Disconnected *** See Also: @emit, @pemit, \\
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SQL

SQL is available in two flavors in RhostMUSH, both are built in and both can be ran at the same time. SQLITE: This is a 'lite' form of SQL. It has a good solid base, but doesn't offer some of the more advanced features that MySQL/MariaDB has. The hosting server must have a workign SQLITE library to successfully link to and use this database offering. MySQL/MariaDB: This is an advanced form of SQL. It allows all the feature-rich capabilities of a fully function SQL engine. The hosting server must have mysql or mariadb to be able to link to and use this offering. See Also: sqlite_query(), @sql, @sqlconnect, @sqldisconnect, sql(), sqlon, sqloff(), sqlping()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SQL()

Function: sql(<SQL statement> [,<delim>,[<field delim>]]) sqlescape(<SQL statement> This function sends a SQL statement to an external SQL database and returns the results. The user must be wizard or immortal. On failure, or a problem with executing the SQL statement, the function returns #-1. If multiple rows are returned, each row will be delimited by <delim>; if <delim> is not specified, a space will be used. If multiple fields are returned, each field will be delimited by <field delim> if specified, or <delim> if not, or a space by default. Please not that special characters to mush (%, {, }, [, ], (, ), \) may have to be escaped for use in queries. Please use ' for quotes for fields. Only wizards+ can use this feature. Examples: (borrowed from TinyMUSH3's help file) > @sql SELECT player_name, dbref_num FROM test WHERE race='Vampire' Row 1, Field 1: Nos Row 1, Field 2: 4 Row 2, Field 1: Caine Row 2, Field 2: 389 > &VAMPS me = SELECT player_name, dbref_num FROM test WHERE race='Vampire' ORDER BY player_name > say [sql(v(VAMPS))] -- [sql(v(VAMPS),|)] You say "Caine 389 Nos 4 -- Caine|389|Nos|4" > @sql UPDATE test SET race='Vampire' WHERE dbref_num=672 SQL query touched 1 row. > say [sql(v(VAMPS),|,)] -- [sql(v(VAMPS),|,/)] You say "Caine 389|Nos 4|Rufus 672 -- Caine/389|Nos/4|Rufus/672" See Also: sqlescape(), @sql, sqlon(), sqloff(), @sqlconnect, @sqldisconnect, sqlping(), esclist(), unesclist()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SQLESCAPE()

Function: sqlescape(<string>) This function performs SQL-server-implemented escaping of <string>. It's important to escape arbitrary data before passing it to the sql() function, or @sql command, to prevent SQL injection attacks. When used in an SQL query, the results of an sqlescape() function should be enclosed in single quotes. Note: You must be a wizard (or higher) to utilize this function. Example: > say sqlescape(You don't say) You say "You don\'t say" See Also: sql(), @sql, sqlon(), sqloff(), @sqlconnect, @sqldisconnect, sqlping(), esclist(), unesclist()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SQLITE_QUERY()

Function: sqlite_query(<db>,<query>[,<cdel>[,<rdel>[,<arg1>,...,<argN>]]]) This function executes the given query on a SQLite database. The database is automatically created when necessary, so no additional set-up is needed to begin using SQLite. The default column delimiter is '|', and the default row delimiter is '^'. Note that SQL statements often contain characters like ',', '(', or ')', so it can be particularly helpful to save queries in an attribute and use V() or U() to access them. Since sqlite_query supports parameterized queries, this is even easier. The second INSERT statement below demonstrates parameterized queries. One important note is that the column and row delimiter arguments are still required for all queries, even though they are only used for queries that return data, such as SELECT queries. The arguments are the <db> [dbname], <query> [database query], <cdel> [column delimiter], <rdel> [row delimiter], and <arg1> through <argN> which are the parameters. {see SQLITE_QUERY2 for examples}
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SQLITE_QUERY2

(CONTINUED) Function: sqlite_query(<db>,<query>[,<cdel>[,<rdel>[,<arg1>,...,<argN>]]]) Example: > @va me = CREATE TABLE test ( testFieldA STRING, testFieldB STRING ) Set. > say sqlite_query( testdb, v(va) ) You say "" > @va me = INSERT INTO test VALUES ( 'a', 'b' ) Set. > say sqlite_query( testdb, v(va) ) You say "" > say sqlite_query( testdb, SELECT * FROM test ) You say "a|b" > @va me = INSERT INTO test VALUES ( ?, ? ) Set. > say sqlite_query( testdb, v(va), , , c, d ) You say "" > say sqlite_query( testdb, SELECT * FROM test ) You say "a|b^c|d" See Also: @cluster
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SQLOFF()

Function: sqloff() This function is essentially just the function equivelant of @sqlconnect. Only wizards+ can use this feature. Example: > say sqloff() You say "0" See Also: @sqlconnect, sqloff(), @sqldisconnect, @sql, sql(), sqlescape(), sqlping()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SQLON()

Function: sqlon() This function is essentially just the function equivelant of @sqlconnect. Only wizards+ can use this feature. Example: > say sqlon() You say "0" See Also: @sqlconnect, sqloff(), @sqldisconnect, @sql, sql(), sqlescape(), sqlping()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SQLPING()

Function: sqlping() This function returns '0' if the database is alive and active, or non-zero (usually '1') if the database has an error with connectivity. Example: > say sqlping() You say "0" See Also: @sqlconnect, sqloff(), @sqldisconnect, @sql, sql(), sqlescape(), sqlon()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SQRT()

Function: sqrt(<number>) Returns the square root of <number>. <number> may be a floating point number, and a floating point result is returned. <number> may not be negative. Examples: > say sqrt(2) You say "1.414214" > say sqrt(100) You say "10" > say sqrt(0) You say "0" > say sqrt(-1) You say "#-1 SQUARE ROOT OF NEGATIVE" See Also: power(), power10()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SQUISH()

Function: squish(string) This function takes out all leading and ending spaces and reduces all spaces in-between to only one space. Example: >say squish([space(10)]hi![space(10)]Bye![space(10)]) You say "hi! Bye!" See Also: s(), trim(), edit(), tr()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SQUISH()

Function squish(<string>[,<delimeter> [,<count>]) This function will remove multiple spaces (or specified delimiter) from the string. This is meant for the ability to remove excess spaces from strings. The delimeter defaults to a space. You may specify a <count> of how many repeated characters will be inserted between the values in the string. The count defaults to 1. Examples: > @wait 0=@va me=Test[space(20)]Test Set. > say u(va) You say "Test Test" > say squish(u(va)) You say "Test Test" > say squish(u(va),,5) You say "Test Test" > @vb me=TestaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaTest Set. > say u(vb) You say "TestaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaTest" > say squish(u(vb),a) You say "TestaTest" > say squish(u(vb),a,5) You say "TestaaaaaTest" See Also: s(), strip(), creplace(), trim()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STACK

Topic: STACK Command lists that are run on objects can have up to 10 stack values named %0 through %9 (or [v(0)] through [v(9)]). Stack values can be set by the @trigger command, or by matching wildcard characters in the Listen attribute (in the case of the Ahear, Aahear, and Amhear attributes). Example: > @listen item = * foo * Set. > @ahear item = "-->[v(1)]<-- bar -->[v(0)]<-- Set. > say Fee fie foo fum You say "Fee fie foo fum" item says "-->fum"<-- bar -->Wizard says "Fee fie<--" See Also: setq(), r(), setr(), nameq(), SUBSTITUTIONS
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STARTSECS()

Function: startsecs() Returns a string which is the time the MUSH last started in seconds. Example: > say startsecs() You say "2324234" See Also: startime(), secs(), rebootsecs(), reboottime(), msecs()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STARTTIME()

Function: starttime() Returns a string which is the time the MUSH last started. The time is in the same format as the TIME() function returns. Example: > say starttime() You say "Sat Dec 7 00:09:13 1991 See Also: convtime(), reboottime(), startsecs(), rebootsecs(), msecs()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STATS()

Function: stats([<player>]) This function returns information about the number of objects on the MUSH, much like the @stats command. If the argument is omitted or is 'all', then the stats for the entire MUSH are returned, otherwise the stats for the named player are returned. You can only get stats for yourself. The stats are returned as a set of 6 numbers, in the same order as reported by the @stats command: total objects, rooms, exits, things, players, and garbage. This command costs as much as the equivalent @stats command (IE: '@stats/all' or '@stats <player>', not the free '@stats'). Examples: > @stats me 6 objects = 0 rooms, 0 exits, 5 things, 1 players. (0 garbage) > say stats(me) You say "6 0 0 5 1 0" > say stats() You say "377 51 165 134 20 7" > @stats/all 377 objects = 51 rooms, 165 exits, 134 things, 20 players. (7 garbage) See Also: @stats, @search, search(), searchng(), searchobjid(), searchngobjid()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STDERR()

Function: stderr(<string> [,<key>]) This function will take the input string and optionally redirect it based on it being a recognized function error (starting with #-1) or not. By default, this function will null out the error entirely. The following keys are available: 0 - null the output of the string that starts with #-1 (default) 1 - null the output of the string that starts with #-1 In addition, notify() to the player the actual error that started with #-1 so it's no longer part of the function stack. Examples: > say [iter(1 3 5 [lrand(1,3)],##)] You say "1 3 5 #-1 FUNCTION (LRAND) EXPECTS 3 OR 4 ARGUMENTS [RECEIVED 2]" > say [iter(1 3 5 [stderr(lrand(1,3))],##)] You say "1 3 5" > say [iter(1 3 5 [stderr(lrand(1,3),1)],##)] STDError: #-1 FUNCTION (LRAND) EXPECTS 3 OR 4 ARGUMENTS [RECEIVED 2] You say "1 3 5" See Also: null(), @@()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STEP()

Function: step([<obj>/]<attr>,<list>,<step size>[,<delim>[,<output delim>]]) This function takes elements of <list>, <step size> elements at a time, and passes them to the function defined by <attr>, as %0, %1, %2, etc. The number of elements in the list does not need to be evenly divisible by the step size. If no delimiters are provided, a space is used as the delimiter. The step size must be at least 1, and no greater than 30. Calling this function with a step size of 1 is equivalent to using map(). Anything over argument 9 (%9) can be called with v(). Such as v(10), v(20), and so forth. Example: > &print_line me = %r%0 -- %1 -- %2 Set. > say [step(print_line,1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8,3)] You say " 1 -- 2 -- 3 4 -- 5 -- 6 7 -- 8 --" This function provided for compatibility with TinyMUSH 3.0 See Also: while(), map(), munge(), iter(), columns(), inf()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STICKY

Flag: STICKY(S) If a thing is STICKY, it goes home when dropped (See HOMES). If a room is STICKY, its drop-to is delayed until the last person leaves (See DROP-TOs). Only meaningful for things and rooms. See Also: HOMES, DROP-TOS
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STR()

Function: str(<string>,<match>) The str function works very similar to after() and very much like the C function strstr. This takes the string starting at the first match and returns that string to the end of that string. This function runs faster than the after() function. Examples: > say str(This is a test,his) You say "his is a test" See Also: nostr(), before(), after()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STRALLOF()

Function: ofparse(<type>, [<eval1> [,<eval2> ... <evalN or delim>]]) Type 1&3: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <default>) Type 2&4: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <output separator>) Type 5&7: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <default>) Type 6&8: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <output separator>) This function will take each <eval> and returns it based on the <type>. The following types exist: 1 -- Issue a firstof(). Essentially return the first <eval> that is a true boolean. This stops evaluation on first true <eval>. The <default> is returned if no evals are met. The <default> is the assumed argument if only passed a single argument. 2 -- Issue an allof(). Essentially returning every <eval> that is a true boolean. This evaluates every argument. 3 -- This is the reverse of '1'. It returns the first <eval> that is a false boolean. IT stops evaluation on first false <eval>. This again assumes <default> if no other arguments. 4 -- This is the reverse of '2'. It returns every false <eval> boolean. This evaluates every argument. 5 -- Issue a strfirstof(). Essentially returns the first <eval> that is a non-null string. This stops evaluation on first non-null <eval>. 6 -- Issues a strallof(). Essentially returns every <eval> that is a non-null string. This evaluates everyu argument. 7 -- This is the reverse of '5'. It essentially will either return a null or the default value. 8 -- This is the reverse of '6'. It essentially will return a list of nulls if you have such in your list. This evaluates every argument. For PennMUSH function lineup: firstof(x,y) == ofparse(1,x,y) allof(x,y,z) == ofparse(2,x,y,z) strfirstof(x,y) == ofparse(5,x,y) strallof(x,y,z) == ofparse(6,x,y,z) { see 'help ofparse2' for examples }
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STRCAT()

Function: strcat(<string>[,<string2>,...,<stringx>]) Returns the strings concatinated with no spaces between them. Example: > say strcat(this,is,a,test) You say "thisisatest" > say strcat(one,2,three,4) You say "one2three4" See Also: cat()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STRDISTANCE()

Function: strdistance(<string1>, <string2> [,<type> [,<damareu match>]]) This function will calculate the levenshtein distance between two strings. This basically is the value calculated by the number of letters that differ between the two strings entered. If either string fed to this function is null, it returns a -1. You may specify the <type> of '1' to expressly require case insensitivity in the matching. The default behavior is case sensitivity. The optional forth argument enables damareu style matching which considers the transposing of characters a single difference istead of two. Examples: > say [strdistance(this,thiz)] You say "1" > say [strdistance(this,This)] You say "1" > say [strdistance(this,This,1)] You say "0" > say [strdistance(the,teh)] You say "2" > say [strdistance(the,teh,,1)] You say "1" See Also: comp()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STREQ()

Function: streq(<string1>,<string2>) This function takes two strings and compares them. If they match, it returns a '1', if not, it returns a '0'. This is not case sensitive. Examples: > streq(this is a test,THIS is A TesT) You say "1" > streq(this is a test,this is a test?) You say "0" See Also: comp(), ncomp(), match(), member()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STREVAL()

Function: streval(<string>, <evaluation level> [,<arg>,<arg2>,...,<argN>]) This function works similar to u() or eval() where it takes the <string> then evaluates it according to the permission of <evaluation level>. You must be equal to or less than the bitlevel specified or it assumes your own level. By default, none of the arguments passed will be evaluated. Evaluation Levels allowed: CIT[IZEN] -- Mortal (bit level 1) GUILD[MASTER] -- Staff (bit level 2) ARCH[ITECT] -- Staff (bit level 3) COUN[CILOR] -- Staff (bit level 4) ROY[ALTY] -- Staff (bit level 5) -- This is a full Wizard IMM[ORTAL] -- Staff (bit level 6) -- This is essentially #1 GOD -- Staff (bit level 7) -- Can only be ran as #1 Examples: (assuming your a full wizard (royalty)) > say streval(My bitlevel: [bittype(me)],immortal) You say "5" (immortal is above your lvl, so ignores) > say streval(My bitlevel: [bittype(me)],councilor) You say "4" > say streval(My bitlevel: [bittype(me)] -- Arg %0,citizen,foo!)] You say "1 -- Arg foo!" > say streval(NoEval: %0 ... Eval: [s(%0)],citizen,[add(1,1)]) You say "Noeval: [add(1,1)] ... Eval: 2" > say streval(Test: [s(%0)],citizen,[bittype(me)]) You say "Test: 1" See Also: ueval(), u(), default(), subeval(), sandbox(), objeval(), @lfunction
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STRFIRSTOF()

Function: ofparse(<type>, [<eval1> [,<eval2> ... <evalN or delim>]]) Type 1&3: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <default>) Type 2&4: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <output separator>) Type 5&7: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <default>) Type 6&8: ofparse(<type>,[<eval1> ,<eval2> ... <evalN>], <output separator>) This function will take each <eval> and returns it based on the <type>. The following types exist: 1 -- Issue a firstof(). Essentially return the first <eval> that is a true boolean. This stops evaluation on first true <eval>. The <default> is returned if no evals are met. The <default> is the assumed argument if only passed a single argument. 2 -- Issue an allof(). Essentially returning every <eval> that is a true boolean. This evaluates every argument. 3 -- This is the reverse of '1'. It returns the first <eval> that is a false boolean. IT stops evaluation on first false <eval>. This again assumes <default> if no other arguments. 4 -- This is the reverse of '2'. It returns every false <eval> boolean. This evaluates every argument. 5 -- Issue a strfirstof(). Essentially returns the first <eval> that is a non-null string. This stops evaluation on first non-null <eval>. 6 -- Issues a strallof(). Essentially returns every <eval> that is a non-null string. This evaluates everyu argument. 7 -- This is the reverse of '5'. It essentially will either return a null or the default value. 8 -- This is the reverse of '6'. It essentially will return a list of nulls if you have such in your list. This evaluates every argument. For PennMUSH function lineup: firstof(x,y) == ofparse(1,x,y) allof(x,y,z) == ofparse(2,x,y,z) strfirstof(x,y) == ofparse(5,x,y) strallof(x,y,z) == ofparse(6,x,y,z) { see 'help ofparse2' for examples }
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STRFUNC()

Function: strfunc(<function>, <list of arguments>[,<delim>]) The strfunc (string function) function is used to transform a string of arguments into separate identified arguments and feed them into the specified function. If you do not have access to the function or if you give the target function an invalid number of arguments, an error message will be displayed. This in effect will turn any function in the game into a string oriented function. Thus the name, 'strfunc'. Examples: > say add(1,2,3,4) You say "10" > say strfunc(add,1 2 3 4) You say "10" > say strfunc(add,1@2@3@4,@) You say "10" > say hastype(me,player) You say "1" > say strfunc(hastype,me player) You say "1" > say switch(add(1,1),2,match,1,nope,0,nope,nope) You say "match" > say strfunc(switch,add(1,1) 2 match 1 nope 0 nope nope) You say "match" See Also: strmath(), ladd(), lsub(), ldiv(), lmul()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

string functions

Function Lists: String Functions accent() - Apply high order bit accent/umlaut/etc on strings. after() - Returns the contents of a string after the specified word. andchr() - Returns 1 if specified string contains specified characters. before() - Returns the contents of a string before the specified word. brackets() - Returns a count of left and right (,{ and [ in a string capstr() - Capitalizes a string. case() - Case is like switch(), but does not do wildcard matching. caseall() - Like case(), but will match all cases not just the first. cat() - Concaternates two strings together. center() - Centers text on a specified width. chomp() - Strips carriage returns from start, end or both of a string. columns() - Powerful column formatting tool. comp() - Compares two strings. creplace() - Like replace(), but works on characters instead of words. decode64() - Decode a 64 compressed string. decrypt() - Decrypt a string based on an offset. delete() - Deletes characters from a string. edit() - Edits a string, replacing, prepending or appending text. editansi() - Edits the ansi encoding of a string. elementpos() - Return the character(s) specified by the positions. encode64() - Encode a string to compressed 64. encrypt() - Encrypt a string based on an offset. escape() - Adds escape characters to some special characters. escapex() - Like escape() but allows specifying characters not to escape. esclist() - Escape optionally specified characters from a string. eval() - Evaluates code. garble() - Garbles input by replacing text. ifelse() - Returns true if an expression evaluates as true. isalnum() - Returns true if first character of input is alphanumeric. isalpha() - Returns true if first character of input is an alpha char. isdbref() - Returns true if passed a valid dbref. isdigit() - Returns true if first character of input is a digit. { Continued in string functions2 }
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

string functions2

Continued from String Functions. isnum() - Returns true if input is a number. isobjid() - Returns true if input is an objid. ispunct() - Returns true if first character of input is a punctuation. isspace() - Returns true if first character of input is a whitespace. istag() - Returns true if passed a valid tag. isword() - Returns true if the argument contains only alpha characters. isxdigit() - Returns true if first character of input is a hexadecimal. lcstr() - Lowercases a string. left() - Extracts X characters from a string, starting from the left. lit() - Returns a string as-is, without formatting or evaluation. ljc() - Left justifies and cuts a string to a specified width. ljust() - Pads a string with trailing fill characters. merge() - Merges two strings together. mid() - Extracts X characters from a string, from anywhere inside it. mwords() - Returns the number of words in a string (with multi-delim). nostr() - The exact opposite of str(). notchr() - Returns true if NONE of the specified chars are in string. numpos() - Returns the total number of matches of a character in string. ofparse() - Returns various manipulations of evaluated strings. orchr() - Returns true if any of the specified chars are in a string. parsestr() - Parses a string according to formatting rules. pedit() - Like edit(), but with PennMUSH functionality. pos() - Returns the position of where a substring begins in a string. printf() - Formats text left, center, right, or stretched justification. randpos() - Like totpos(), but totally randomizes output. repeat() - Repeats input X times. replace() - Replaces a word in a list at a specified position. right() - Extracts X characters from a string, starting from the right. rjc() - Right justifies and cuts a string to a specified width. rjust() - Right justifies a string by padding it with specified char. rotl() - Rotates a string X characters to the left. rotr() - Rotates a string X characters to the right. s() - Force evaluation of a string. { Continued in string functions3 }
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

string functions3

Continued from string functions2 sandbox() - Evaluates code with specific function restrictions scramble() - Scrambles a string, returning the characters randomly. secure() - Removes special characters from a string. securex() - Like secure(), but you can specify characters not to remove. shl() - Performs a leftwards bitshift on a number. shr() - Performs a rightwards bitshift on a number. shuffle() - Shuffles the words of a string. space() - Returns X number of whitespace. splice() - Splices two lists together. squish() - Removes excess spaces or delimiters from a string. stderr() - Convert all #-1 errors to notify() and not the stack. str() - Like after(), and similar to C strstr(). strdistance() - Calculates the levenshtein distance between two strings. streq() - Compares two strings, returning true if they match. streval() - Evaluates the string based on the permission level specified. strip() - Strips out every occurrence of a character in a string. stripaccents()- Strip accents from specified string. strlen() - Returns the length of a string. strlenraw() - Returns the length of the RAW string. strlenvis() - Returns the length of the VISUAL string. strmatch() - Returns true if a pattern is found in a string. subeval() - Performs pronoun substitution on a string. subnetmatch() - Returns true if an IP address is part of a subnet. switch() - Powerful string-pattern conditional. switchall() - Like switch(), but matches all occurrences of a pattern. t() - Unifies MUSH responses of 0, null or #-* to return 0. template() - Direct WYSIWYG substitution in a template string. totpos() - Returns all the positions of a match in a string. tr() - Transforms a string based on find and replace lists. translate() - Translates special characters to percent substitutions. trim() - Trims trailing and leading spaces from a string. ucstr() - Upper-cases a string. unesclist() - Escape optionally specified characters from a string. wordpos() - Returns the position of a word in a string. words() - Returns the number of words in a string. wrap() - Formats a string by wrapping it, much like columns() wrapcolumns() - Like wrap() and columns(). See help for more. xorchr() - Returns true if only ONE occurrence of a character is found.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STRIP()

Function: strip(<string1>,<string2> [,<type>]) This function strips out every occurance of every character of <string2> from <string1> and returns <string1>. The strip function is case sensitive. If <type> is specified as '1', then the functionality is reversed and it will only keep all characters in <string1> that exist in <string2>. Examples: > say strip(This is a test,is) You say "Th a tet" > say strip(abcdefgABCDEFG,azGy!7$B) You say "bcdefgACDEF" > say strip(This is a test,is,1) You say "isiss" See Also: @edit, edit(), editansi(), garble(), chomp(), regedit(), elementpos()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STRIPACCENTS()

Function: stripaccents(<string>) Returns the string with accented characters converted to non-accented. This function assumes the ISO 8859-1 character set. Example: > say stripaccents(Aul(e-with-diaeresis)) You say "Aule" See Also: chr(), asc(), strip(), stripansi(), tr(), accent(), ACCENTS.
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STRIPANSI()

Function: stripansi(<string>) Returns the string with all ansi codes removed. Example: > say stripansi(ansi(hr,red)) You say "red" See Also: NO_FLASH, ANSI, ANSICOLOR, stripaccents(), ansipos()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STRLEN()

Function: strlen(<string>) strlenvis(<string>) strlenraw(<string>) Returns the number of characters in <string>. Example: > say strlen(This is a test) You say "14" > say strlen(Would you like coffee, or perhaps tea) You say "37" The strlenvis() function adjusts the string to the VISUAL size of the string when using chr() codes (which are normally 6 characters each). This is so you can specially padd when using special chr() values. The strlenraw() function displays the raw length of the string, including any 'markup' codes that are generally used for accents and raw ansi. This is mostly intended when you need to see the absolute length of a string for length checks or the like. See Also: words(), wordpos()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STRLENRAW()

Function: strlen(<string>) strlenvis(<string>) strlenraw(<string>) Returns the number of characters in <string>. Example: > say strlen(This is a test) You say "14" > say strlen(Would you like coffee, or perhaps tea) You say "37" The strlenvis() function adjusts the string to the VISUAL size of the string when using chr() codes (which are normally 6 characters each). This is so you can specially padd when using special chr() values. The strlenraw() function displays the raw length of the string, including any 'markup' codes that are generally used for accents and raw ansi. This is mostly intended when you need to see the absolute length of a string for length checks or the like. See Also: words(), wordpos()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STRLENVIS()

Function: strlen(<string>) strlenvis(<string>) strlenraw(<string>) Returns the number of characters in <string>. Example: > say strlen(This is a test) You say "14" > say strlen(Would you like coffee, or perhaps tea) You say "37" The strlenvis() function adjusts the string to the VISUAL size of the string when using chr() codes (which are normally 6 characters each). This is so you can specially padd when using special chr() values. The strlenraw() function displays the raw length of the string, including any 'markup' codes that are generally used for accents and raw ansi. This is mostly intended when you need to see the absolute length of a string for length checks or the like. See Also: words(), wordpos()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STRMATCH()

Function: strmatch(<string>,<pattern>) This function matches <pattern> against the entire <string>, returning 1 if it matches and 0 if it does not. The case of the characters being matched is not significant. The pattern may contain the wildcards '*' and '?'. '?' matches any one character, while '*' matches any number of characters, including none. So 's?x' would match 'sex' or 'six', but not to 'socx', but 's*x' would match any of them. Examples: > say strmatch(This is a test,*Test) You say "1" > say strmatch(This is a test,*This) You say "0" > say strmatch(This is a test,*is*is*) You say "1" See Also: match(), member(), nummatch(), nummember(), totmatch(), totmember()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

strmath()

Function: strmath (syntax follows) strmath(<str>,<num>,<math>[,<dlm>,<sep>,<st>,<amt>,<idlm>,<isep>,<low>,<hi>) The strmath function is used to apply math to the entire string. Numbers in the string are modified based on the math chosen applied to the number. You may specify optional input and output separators. You may also specify the word to start (<st>) the math on and how many words (<amt>) after the start you wish to use. If no math is specified, '+' is used as a default. The <idlm> and <isep> are inner delimiter and separator to use for the normal delimited string. This is so you can separate values such as: To hit:5|To Damage:10|Base AC:15 Note: It handles floating point notation, so values with decimals are seen. Key: str -- input string num -- value to apply math -- math to use dlm -- delimiter sep -- separator st -- start value amt -- word count idlm -- inner delim isep -- inner sep low -- low val match hi -- high val match You may specify the 'low' and 'hi' values to specify a range of what values you wish to apply the math to. { see 'help strmath2' for value values for <math> and examples }
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

strmath2

Function: strmath (syntax follows) (CONTINUED) strmath(<str>,<num>,<math>[,<dlm>,<sep>,<st>,<amt>,<idlm>,<isep>,<low>,<hi>) Valid <math> arguments are: + - apply addition to all numbers in the string. - - apply subtraction to all numbers in the string. / - apply division to all numbers in the string. * - apply multiplication to all numbers in the string. %% - return remainder of division. (you need to use two %%'s) Valid conditional <math> arguments are: <VALUE - set to <num> for every condition < VALUE (eg. <10) >VALUE - set to <num> for every condition > VALUE (eg. >10) =VALUE - set to <num> for every condition = VALUE (eg. =10) !=VALUE - set to <num> for every condition != VALUE (eg. !=10) <=VALUE - set to <num> for every condition <= VALUE (eg. <=10) >=VALUE - set to <num> for every condition >= VALUE (eg. >=10) Examples: > say strmath(1 fish 2 fish green fish blue fish,10,+) (default) You say "11 fish 12 fish green fish blue fish" > say strmath(1 fish 2 fish green fish blue fish,10,*) You say "10 fish 20 fish green fish blue fish" > say strmath(1 fish 2 fish 3 shoe 4 shoe,10,+,,,3,2) You say "1 fish 12 fish 13 shoe 4 shoe" > say strmath(To hit:5|To Damage:10|Base AC:15,150,+,|,|,1,0,:,:) You say "To hit:155|To Damage:10|Base AC:15" > say strmath(10 beats 5 but is less than 100,0,<40) You say "0 beats 0 but is less than 100" > say strmath(10 beats 5 but is less than 100,0,>40) You say "10 beats 5 but is less than 0" > say strmath(10 beats 5 but is less than 100,0,=5) You say "10 beats 0 but is less than 100" > say strmath(10 beats 5 but is less than 100,0,!=5) You say "0 beats 5 but is less than 0" See Also: add(), sub(), mul(), div(), mod(), strfunc(), spellnum()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

STRTRUNC()

Function: left(<string>, <position> [,<key>]) (Alias): strtrunc(<string>,<position> [,<key>]) Left will take a string and return the left-most position of characters from the string. You may specify a <key> of 1 to tell left() to take the string raw and not do ansi-aware processing. This will speed up the function. The default is '0' which does ansi processing. Note: the config param 'ansi_default' handles if the ansi handling is configured default or not. In which case the 'key' is reversed. Example: > say left(this is a test,5) You say "this " > say left(this is a test,10000) You say "this is a test" > say left(this is a test,0) You say "" See Also: right(), mid(), delete(), ljc(), rjc()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SUB()

Function: sub(<number1>,<number2>[,<numberN>]...) Returns the result of subtracting <number2> from <number1>. The numbers may be floating point numbers, and a floating point result is returned. Numbers may be floating point numbers, and a floating point result is returned. Example: > say sub(5,2) You say "3" See Also: add(), div(), mod(), mul()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SUBEVAL()

Function: subeval(<string> [,,<key>]) subeval(<thing>, <attribute> [,<key>]) This function will evaluate <string> by parsing all substitutions but will not evaluate functions, built in or otherwise. The second form will evaluate <attribute> from <thing> parsing all substitutions but not evaluating any functions, built in or otherwise. You must be able to control <thing> to fetch the attribute. You may specify an optional <key> in both forms of 1 to force a double-parse of substitutions. Example: > @va me=[add(1,1)] %# %n %%# Set > say [subeval(%# %N %%# [sub(1,1)])] You say "#123 Tester %# [sub(1,1)]" > say [subeval(%# %N %%# [sub(1,1)],,1)] You say "#123 Tester #123 [sub(1,1)]" > say [subeval(me,va)] You say "[add(1,1)] #123 Tester %#" > say [subeval(me,va,1)] You say "[add(1,1)] #123 Tester #123" See Also: s(), eval(), sandbox(), ueval()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SUBJ()

Function: subj(<object>) Returns the proper subjective pronoun (he, she, it, they) for referring to <object>, based on the object's Sex attribute. You must either control or be near <object>. Example: > @sex me=male Set. > say subj(me) You say "he" See Also: SUBSTITUTIONS, obj(), poss(), aposs()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SUBNETMATCH()

Function: subnetmatch(<ip>,<netstart>,<netmask>) subnetmatch(<ip>,<netstart>/<CIDR>) This function allows you to check wether an IP falls into a certain subnet or not. The function allows you to use either a format specifying the subnet address and netmask, or the common CIDR format. It returns 1 if the IP address is part of the subnet, 0 if it is not. Examples: subnetmatch(123.123.123.123, 123.0.0.0, 255.0.0.0) -> 1 subnetmatch(123.123.123.123, 123.0.0.0, 255.255.0.0) -> 0 subnetmatch(123.123.123.123, 123.0.0.0/8) -> 1 subnetmatch(123.123.123.123, 123.0.0.0/16) -> 0
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SUBSTITUTIONS

Topic: SUBSTITUTIONS All messages may contain %-substitutions, which evaluate to gender-specific pronouns if the player's gender is set or to other useful information. Information returned is based on the player that caused the message to be displayed, not the object that stored the message or which is running the action list. The substitutions available are: %s, %S = Name, he, she, it, they. (subjective) %o, %O = Name, him, her, it, them. (objective) %p, %P = Name's, his, her, its, their. (possessive) %a, %A = Name's, his, hers, its, theirs. (absolute possessive) %n, %N = the player's name. %k, %K = the player's colorized/accented name. %w, %W = the target dbref# of the twinklock (if applicable) %r = carriage return. %t = tab character. %b = space character. %% = literal '%' character. %0-%9 = Value of positional parameter/stack location 0 through 9. %-<num> = Stack 10+ that are comma delimited or if <num> specified the positional stack location 0 through 999. BANGS supported. %-m = The last command executed that issued @hook. %i0-%i99 = Equivalent to itext(0) through itext(99). [%il for outer] %i_0-%i_99 = Equivalent to inum(0) through inum(99) [%i_l for outer] BANGS supported. Note: '99' depends on recursion limit. %d0-%d9 = Equivalent to dtext(0) through dtext(9). [%dl for outer] Only useable with /inline only. BANGS supported. %q0-%q9 = Value of registers. Basically equivalent to [r(0)] - [r(9)]. Note: You may use %q<label>/%q<0> as well. BANGS supported. %qa-%qz = Extended value of registers. %va-%vz = Contents of attribute va through vz. NOTE: Anything that says BANGS supported may use BANGS for the process. example: %-!!$22 (see if arg 22 contains a string) %q<!!$0> (see if register 0 is a string) %q<!!$foo> (see if register with label 'foo' is a string) %i!!$0 (see if iter()'s itext(0) is a string) %d!!$0 (see if @dolist/inline's dtext(0) is a string) { 'help substitutions2' for more }
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

substitutions2

%# = Database number of the object that caused the message to be displayed or the action list to be run. %: = Database object-id of the object that caused the message to be displayed or the action list to be run. %l = Database number of the location of the object that caused the message to be displayed or the action list to be run. %! = Database number of the object holding the message or running the action list. %@ = Database number of the object immediately calling %! (Caller). This number starts as the same as %#, but can be affected by u()-type functions, zones, and @function. %+ = Show the total arguments a function received. %? = Show current function invocation as well as current nest levels. %c = ANSI substitution or Last Command Executed. %x = ANSI substitution or Last Command Executed. %_ = The TRACE breakpoint marker. See 'help %_' for more. %m = ANSI substitution or Last Command Executed. The functionality of above subs depends on compile options: * ANSI substitution: It takes the next character as the ansi sequence and continues with that sequence till the next one or end of the line. You may also specify 0x## (ie: 0x20) to use extended 256 colors. * Last Command Executed: The substitution contains the whole, unevaluated code of the last command executed. %f = Specify template for accent handler for strings. To see a list of templates, see help on the accent() function. %< = Used for UNICODE (ASCII 160 through 255). Syntax: %<###> This requires the ACCENT toggle to utilize. Note: The functionality of '%c' and '%x' may be switched. Check @list options to check. Note: The functionality of '%f' is only useable if ZENTY_ANSI is enabled. The functionality of '%<' is only useable if ZENTY_ANSI is enabled. The functionality of '%<' requires the ACCENTS toggle. If the letter following the % is capitalized, the first letter of the result of the substitution is also capitalized. Note: %<whatever> is equivalent to [v(<whatever>)], but is more efficient. This _ONLY_ works for @va to @vz attributes currently. Sorry. See Also: GENDER, V(), SHIFT(), ACCENT()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SUCCESS

Topic: SUCCESS You successfully use a player or a thing when you take it (because you passed the lock). You successfully use an exit when you go through it. You successfully use a room when you look around and the room is not locked against you. See Also: get, look, @asuccess, @lock, @osuccess, @success
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SUPER-ROYALTY

Flag: SUPER-ROYALTY (IMMORTAL)(i) This flag when set on a player allows them to be a hybrid wizard. They can basically do anything, see anything, be anything. The only thing they can not do is set or unset this flag or directly affect #1. It's generally wise if you don't annoy these people. See Also: GUILDMASTER, ARCHITECT, COUNCILOR, ROYALTY
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SWITCH()

Function: switch(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>]...[,<dflt>]) The switch function compares <str> against <pat1>, <pat2>, etc (allowing * to match any number of characters and ? to match any 1 character), and returns the corresponding <resN> parameter for the first <patN> pattern that matches. If none match, then the default result <dflt> is returned. Example: > say switch(c,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E) You say "C" > say switch(f,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E) You say "E" > say switch(cab,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E) You say "A" > say switch(f,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D) You say "" ----- if penn_switches enabled > say switch(3,>=2,Y,N) You say "Y" ----- if float_switches enabled > say switch(2.23,>=2.22,Y,N) You say "Y" If configured, you may use #$ as a substition. #$ is substituted with the value of <string>. In this way, the commands in <res11>..<dflt> have a short-hand way of getting at the matched value. Note: The following config parameters effect how this functions. penn_switches -- if enabled allows >, <, >=. <= for math. float_switches -- if enabled allows floating values as well. Refer: '@list options boolean *switch*' to check switch options. See Also: @switch, match(), case(), ifelse(), switchall()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SWITCHALL()

Function: switchall(<str>[,<pat1>,<res1>]...[,<dflt>]) The switchall function compares <str> against <pat1>, <pat2>, etc (allowing * to match any number of characters and ? to match any 1 character), and returns all corresponding <resN> parameters for all <patN> patterns that matches. If none match, then the default result <dflt> is returned. Example: > say switchall(c,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E) You say "C" > say switchall(f,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E) You say "E" > say switchall(cab,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D,E) You say "ABC" > say switchall(f,*a*,A,*b*,B,*c*,C,*d*,D) You say "" ----- if penn_switches enabled > say switch(3,>=2,Y,N) You say "Y" ----- if float_switches enabled > say switch(2.23,>=2.22,Y,N) You say "Y" If configured, you may use #$ as a substition. #$ is substituted with the value of <string>. In this way, the commands in <res11>..<dflt> have a short-hand way of getting at the matched value. Note: The following config parameters effect how this functions. penn_switches -- if enabled allows >, <, >=. <= for math. float_switches -- if enabled allows floating values as well. Refer: '@list options boolean *switch*' to check switch options. See Also: @switch, match(), case(), ifelse(), switch()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

SWITCHES

Topic: SWITCHES Some commands have command switches associated with them that can be used to modify their behavior. For instance, switches on the @ps command control the amount of information displayed, and switches on the @switch command indicate whether to perform all actionlists whose targets match the search string, or just the first. See Also: @list
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

T()

Function: t(<string>) This is a TRUE BOOLEAN function. Returns a '0' if the string is null (empty), a '0', or a # followed by any negative number, or a string containing nothing but spaces. Otherwise, it returns a '1'. Example: > say t() You say "0" > say t(0) You say "0" > say t(#-1) You say "0" > say t(900) You say "1" > say t(this is a test) You say "1" > say t(space(100)) You say "0" See Also: isobjid(), isdbref(), istag(), isspace(), s()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TAG()

Function: tag(<string>) This function returns the #dbref stored behind the tag named <string>. These tags get created with Rhost's tag system ( see 'wizhelp @tag' and 'wizhelp tags' ) by admins, and can be useful to avoid having hardcoded #dbrefs in mushcode. These tags can also be used on-the-fly in the client, for example using something like 'ex tag(weather_globals)' to examine the object of which the #dbref is stored in the 'weather_globals' tag. If a non-existant tagname is supplied in the tag() function, it always returns #-1. NOTE: An alternative to using tag() is to look up a tag with #<tagname> as a replacement for #dbref. For example, "tag(weather_globals)" and "#weather_globals" will return the same #dbref. Also See: help wizhelp tags, wizhelp @tag, wizhelp listtags(), wizhelp tagmatch()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

take

Command: take[/<switch>] <object> take[/<switch>] <exit> take[/<switch>] <object>'s <sub-object> The first form picks up <object> from your location and adds it to your inventory. It will fail if the object is locked against you, or if you are inside a player or object that you don't control and which isn't set ENTER_OK. The second form takes an exit from your location and adds it to you. Anyone inside you may then use the exit to travel to the exit's destination. You may take exits that you own, and exits owned by others in locations that you own. The third form takes <sub-object> from <object> and adds it to your inventory. <object> must be ENTER_OK and <sub-object> must not be locked against you for this to work. The lock on <object> is not checked. { 'help take2' for more }
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

take2

The following switch is recognized: /quiet - Don't perform the @osucc/@asucc or @ofail/@afail attributes on the target object. This switch only works if you control the object. <object> and <sub-object> may be either players or things. 'get' is the same as 'take'. See Also: drop, @afail, @asucc, @fail, @ofail, @osucc, @succ, ENTER_OK, FAILURE, SUCCESS
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TAN()

Function: tan(<number> [,<units>]) Returns the tangent of <number>, expressed in radians. You may specify <units> which are either (r)adians, (g)radians, or (d)egrees. (r)adians are the default. Examples: > say tan(0) You say "0" > say tan(1) You say "1.557408" > say tan(fdiv(pi(),4)) You say "1" See Also: acos(), asin(), atan(), atan2(), cos(), pi(), sin(), ctu(), cosh(), sinh(), tanh()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TANH()

Function: tanh(<number> [,<units>]) Returns the hyperbolic tangent of <number>, expressed in radians. You may specify <units> which are either (r)adians, (g)radians, or (d)egrees. (r)adians are the default. Examples: > say tanh(0) You say "0" > say tanh(1) You say "0.761594" > say tanh(fdiv(pi(),4)) You say "1.324609" See Also: acos(), asin(), atan(), atan2(), cos(), pi(), sin(), ctu(), cosh(), sinh()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

taste

Command: taste [<object>] Displays the tastes of <object>, or the location you're in if you don't specify an object. Specifying object as <name> or #<dbref> or 'me' or 'here' is legal. You can also use taste to taste objects held by other people. Just use 'taste <person>'s <object>'. See Also: look, smell, touch, listen, @staste, @sataste, @sotaste
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TEL()

Function: tel(<obj> [<obj2>...],<loc> [<loc2>...] [,<silent>]) This function works like @tel/list works. It will teleport one or more objects to one or more destinations. It follows the same permissions and restrictions that @tel will follow. The SIDEFX flag is required for this function. The value of the optional argument 'silent' can be either 0 or 1. If set to 1 then the attributes 'atport', 'otport', 'oxtport' and 'tport' are not evaluated. Type @list options to see if this side-effect is enabled. The last example teleports you to #0, bob to #2, and joe to #4. Example: > say tel(me,#0) You say "" The Beginning(#0) A simple room > @tel/list me=#0 The Beginning(#0) A simple room > say tel(me bob joe,#0 #2 #4) You say "" See Also: @tel, move(), SIDEEFFECTS
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TELOK

Flag: TELOK([T]) The TELOK flag is used to enable bitted players (staff) the ability to set up so that they can be teleported around as if they were a mortal. This is handy in testing code where @teleport is used. See Also: JUMP_OK, @teleport
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TEMPLATE()

Function: template(<string>, <arg0> [,<arg1>, ..., <arg9>]) This function will take an input string <string> as the template string and do substitution based on the arguments you pass to it. It will walk through each of the arguments one character at a time and replace the specified characters in the template. The following characters specify each of the template replacements in question: 1 or more 0's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg0 1 or more 1's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg1 1 or more 2's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg2 1 or more 3's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg3 1 or more 4's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg4 1 or more 5's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg5 1 or more 6's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg6 1 or more 7's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg7 1 or more 8's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg8 1 or more 9's -- will be a one to one replacement of chars in arg9 You may have any order of substitions in the template. You may use numbers that have no arguments. In such a case the template will be replaced with a space character. If the argument is shorter than the number of substitutions in the template, spaces are used as filler. Tabs will be replaced with a single space. This function is ansi and accent aware. Examples: > say template(test <0123> test <0123> test,aaaaaaa,bbbbbbb,cccccc,dddddd) You say "test <abcd> test <abcd> test" > say template(test 001 wheee 100,----,<>) You say "test --< wheee >--" > think template(>>> 000000 <<<%r>>> 000000 <<<,abcde%rtuvwy) >>> abcde <<< >>> tuvwy <<< See Also: printf(), edit(), regedit(), template()
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]

TEMPLE

Flag: TEMPLE(T) The TEMPLE flag is no longer a part of RhostMUSH. Check +help for information on +sacrifice. See Also: score
[PREV] [TOP] [NEXT]
